loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: pay educational expenses like books, photocopies and others.

loans.name: Florence's Group

texts.en:
Florence's group is comprised of 2 hard working women. Florence is 20 years old and lives in the town of Nakifuma in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past 3 years, Florence has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells essential commodities. 

To help expand her business, Florence has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more essential goods like sugar and salt for the business, and will help Florence to generate greater profits and take good care of her family's basic needs. Florence hopes that in the future she will be able to open up another retail shop. 

Florence is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more essential goods like sugar and salt for the business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy disposable cutlery

loans.name: Luvuno

texts.en:
Luvuno appreciates her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards.

She is requesting a loan to purchase wheat flour, cooking oil, maize flour and rice for her business. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, cooking oil, maize flour and rice for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase cement and ironwork to build a workshop.

loans.name: Frorence

texts.en: Florence is forty-six years old. She is the mother of six children, who all go to school. She has been selling foodstuffs and retail items in her boutique for the past thirteen years. She has requested the loan to buy more inventory such as beans and maize for sale in her boutique. She plans to use the profits for paying her children's school fees.

loans.use: To buy beans and maize to sell.

loans.name: Tatu

texts.en:
Tatu appreciates her previous Kiva loan which improved her living standards. 

She is requesting a loan to purchase books to sell. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. 

Tatu thanks Yehu Microfinance Trust for its financial support.

loans.use: to purchase books to sell.

loans.name: Aminah

texts.en:
Aminah is 20 years old and lives in the town of Nakifuma in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has 2 children who are both currently in school. For the past 2 years, Aminah has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells shoes. 

To help expand her business, Aminah has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more shoes to sell, and will help Aminah to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Aminah hopes that, in the future, she will be able to open up a retail shop. 

Aminah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more shoes to sell

loans.name: Susana

texts.es:
Susana es estudiante de un Instituto de Formación Docente, estudia para ser profesora de Escolares Básicas.
Comenta que su pareja es quien la ayuda siempre y la apoya en todo lo que hace. Susana es una persona que quiere ser alguien en la vida, es por ello que se está esforzando.
Pide este préstamo para poder pagar sus cuotas de la universidad, ya que de esa forma podrá seguir con sus estudios, luchando por mejorar.
texts.en: Susana is a student at a Teacher Training Institute. She is studying to become an elementary school teacher. She told us that her partner is always helping her and that he supports her with everything that she does. Susana is a person who wants to make something of herself in life and because of this she is striving. She asked for this loan to be able to pay for her university tuition so that she will be able to continue with her studies and to struggle to improve herself.

loans.use: to pay university tuition.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma, 23 years old, lives in the town of Nakifuma in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has 2 children, with one currently in school. For the past 2 years, Fatuma has been working hard to manage her restaurant, which sells cooked food. 

To help expand her business, Fatuma has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to stock more fresh food for sale, and will help Fatuma to generate greater profits and take good care of her family's basic needs. Fatuma hopes that, in the future, she will be able to improve the business more. 

Fatuma is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to stock more fresh food for sale

loans.name: Yvonne

texts.en:
Yvonne is a 33-year-old who lives in the District of Nyanga, Zimbabwe. She is divorced and has a one-year-old child. For the past 3 months, Yvonne has run a flea market stall selling clothes. She has been volunteering as a community health trainer for seven years. Yvonne was recently elected as the secretary of her district’s branch of CAMA – Camfed’s alumni network.

Yvonne intends to use this Kiva loan to make bulk purchases of clothes for children, women and men. She plans to expand to a general dealer shop which will help to boost her business and serve more customers.

loans.use: to make bulk purchases of clothes

loans.name: El Hadji Assane

texts.fr: El hadji Assane est un homme qui vit avec sa famille dans un quartier de la place. Marié et père de famille, il évolue dans la couture, il est tailleur de profession. Il demande ce crédit d’un montant de 300.000F pour acheter une machine et des tissus pour satisfaire ses clients. Il a une expérience de 8 ans et commence sa journée à 10h pour la terminer à 21h. Ill prend en charge toutes les charges des dépenses quotidiennes de sa famille. A L’avenir il souhaite  avoir un 2ème atelier de couture dans le marché et cela grâce à l’aide de l’institution.  De ce fait il pourra augmenter ses revenus et améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en: El Hadji Assane is a man who lives with his family in a neighborhood instead. Married and a father, he works with clothes and is a tailor for his profession. He asked for a loan of  300,000F to buy a machine and fabrics to satisfy his customers. He has 8 years of experience and begins his day at 10am to finish at 9pm. He supports all expenses of his family. In the future he wants a second sewing shop in the market and with help from the institution so that he can increase revenues and improve the living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine to fulfill orders

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to make bulk purchases of hair products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase cooking utensils intended for resale

loans.name: Keliam (2) Group

texts.en:
Emmanuel is a micro-entrepreneur in Brazzaville, the Republic of Congo, and the proud owner of a small business selling wood and coal. With six children to support, four of whom are still going through school, Emmanuel has looked to help increase his means of income in recent years. In 2013, Emmanuel discovered and joined HOPE Congo, and is now leading a group of 9 other micro-entrepreneurs within the community bank group KELIAM (2). Emmanuel is currently on his 4th loan cycle with HOPE Congo, and is hoping to take out a loan of 450,000 XAF to help supplement his wood and coal business and to launch a new business activity selling drinks.

In order to gain clients, Emmanuel lowers his prices and rotates his stock. He dreams of one day being a true businessman and opening his own grocery store. In the future, he hopes that his children will finish their education and be able to live well.

loans.use: to purchase additional wood and coal to sell and to branch out into drink sales

loans.name: Nubwenge Group

texts.fr:
Bénoît  fait partie du groupe  Nubwenge  et  habite à Gitega. Il a 39 ans et est marié à Suavis, une cultivatrice. Ensemble ils ont 5 enfants âgés de 9 à 14 ans, dont 3 étudient.

Il fait le commerce de boutique (haricot, sel ,riz,…) depuis  2  ans. 

Il est  à son troisième crédit à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’il  obtient, il  va  augmenter son capital et acheter  des articles de sa boutique en grande quantité (haricot, sel ,riz,…) à revendre, pour gagner plus.
texts.en:
Bénoît belongs to group Nubwenge and lives in Gitega. He is 39 years old and married to Suavis, a farmer. Together they have five children, ages 9 to 14, and three of them go to school.

He has been selling grocery items (such as beans, salt, rice…) for two years.

This is his third loan with Turame. With the loan granted through Kiva, he will increase his capital and purchase grocery items in bulk (e.g. beans, salt, rice…) to resell and earn more.

loans.use: to buy articles for his store (beans, salt, rice...) in bulk.

loans.name: Nkome Nfa Group

texts.en:
Robert is the featured borrower of this group of entrepreneurs. Born 43 years ago in Accra city, Robert is married and has two children. His wife, Alice, is a businesswoman and his children are attending school. 

Robert has been a businessman for 10 years now. He is currently selling soft drinks. Robert will use his share of the loan (GHS 1,000) to expand his business; he will buy 10 cartons of soft drinks and sell to customers. 

This is the fifth loan that Robert and Joyce have applied for loan from ID-Ghana/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their respective businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To buy 10 cartons of soft drinks and sell to customers.

loans.name: Binyomo 3 Group

texts.en: The Binyomo 3 Group is made up of two women who both live in the same neighborhood in Ghana. Rhoda is the group representative. She is 37 years old and married to Ishmeal. Together they have two children, both of whom attend school, and who depend on them and for whom they are responsible. They live together with their children, and both provide for the expenses of their household.Rhoda left school at secondary level and began selling scarves, cutlery sets and pegs for six years. She is very successful with her business, which allows her to provide for her needs and those of her children. She buys her supplies in the market in Accra. She would like to be able to respond better to the demands of her customers, so she has requested her eighth loan, with the other member named Elizabeth, from the field partner. This loan will enable them to fulfill their customers' needs and make more profit. The previous loans was fully and correctly repaid.

loans.use: to buy scarves, cutlery sets and pegs to sell to customers.

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en:
Mabel is 49 years old and single with one dependable child. Mabel works hard to provide for her family. She sells slippers and powder in Accra, Ghana and requested a 1,000 GHS (Ghanian Cedis) loan through ID Ghana to buy more slippers and powder to sell to customers.

Mabel has borrowed and paid back five loans from ID Ghana before this loan. She has been doing this job for eight years.

She successfully paid back her previous loans and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

Mabel aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more slippers and powder to sell to customers.

loans.name: Yahuza

texts.en: Yahuza is a 30-year-old farmer from Ang/Gabas. As a Babban Gona member, Yahuza is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Yahuza can earn up to $2,000/hectare this season from growing maize, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 because this loan gives them access to the required high-yielding inputs such as improved seeds, that significantly impact yield. When asked how he plans to spend the money he makes from selling his maize, Yahuza said, “I plan to use the money I make to expand my farmland", and in five years, I want to become the most profitable farmer in my community”. With this loan, he is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed

loans.name: Fermin

texts.es:
Fermin es divorciado y tiene tres hijos los cuales ya son todos independientes, vive en casa familiar ocupando dos habitaciones pequeñas, la casa se encuentra ubicada en La Paz.
Actualmente trabaja como chófer y a veces hasta muy altas horas de la noche ya que con lo poco que gana debe cubrir los gastos de alimentación y pago de servicios básicos.
Fermin necesita crédito para mantenimiento de su vehículo ya que es su única fuente de ingresos.
texts.en: Fermin is divorced and he has three children who are all independent. He lives in his family home, occupying two small rooms. His house is located in La Paz. Currently he works as a driver, sometimes until very late at night because with the little that he earns he can just cover his food expenses and payments for basic services. Fermin needs a loan to maintain his vehicle because it his only source of income.

loans.use: to maintain his vehicle.

loans.name: Paulina

texts.es: Paulina es casada y tiene 4 hijos Ella vive en El Alto en una casa de adobe que le pertenece a sus familiares  y tiene todos los servicios básicos Paulina se dedica a la carpinteria y a la venta de madera Ella necesita un credito para comprar mayor cantidad de madera que despues pueda vender o usar  para trabajos grandes (ejemplo: encargo de sillas) Por el momento Paulina es la unica fuente de ingresos en el hogar y necesita su ayuda
texts.en: Paulina is married and has 4 children. She lives in El Alto in an adobe house that belongs to her family and she has all of the basic services. Paulina works in carpentry and at selling wood. She needs a loan to buy a greater quantity of wood that she will later be able to sell or use for large projects (example: an order of chairs). For the moment, Paulina is the only source of income in the home and needs your help.

loans.use: to buy a larger quantity of wood.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy sodas, cookies, butter, and others.

loans.name: Thank God Group

texts.en:
The group Thank God will start its third cycle with ID-Ghana. The group is comprised of six members and they are into the sale of commodities including porridge, secondhand shirts, rubber drums, slippers, underwear, and carpentry. They will hold each other responsible for the repayment of the loan.

The loan will benefit the small micro-businesses where Suweba is a member. She says that two years ago she was integrated into the group due to an invitation from a colleague that is a client of the institution. Now she has a business selling porridge. She actually began this business many years ago but was able to increase her sales by selling at the pavement.

This loan is so Suweba can buy millet and firewood to prepare porridge and sell to customers, and to eventually improve her retail space. This work enables her to generate income so that she can support her family. When we asked what she liked about ID-Ghana, Suweba responded that she likes the training offered.

loans.use: To buy millet and firewood to prepare porridge and sell to customers

loans.name: Abadacogora Group

texts.en: Abadacogora means relentless people. The group members sell different items and they have been in the business for the past five years. Gaudence is the group leader and is 42 years old. She is married with three children aged between twelve and twenty six. With the loan, Gaudence would love to buy more foodstuffs such as beans, maize and cassava for sale. The profits from the business will be used to provide for the family and make more savings.

loans.use: to buy more foodstuffs such as beans, maize and cassava for sale.

loans.name: Efrain

texts.es:
Efrain es soltero y no tiene hijos Vive en El Alto en una casa de adobe se dedica a la costura de prendas de vestir (chamarras y sacos), principalmente de tela y fibra. 

Vive en casa de sus padres, ubicada en El Alto Necesita credito para cancelar un curso que le ayudara a mejorar la calidad de su trabajo, en otras palabras, quiere hacer un curso de actualización puesto que Efrain es el unico que aporta economicamente en su hogar
texts.en:
Efrain is single and doesn't have children. He lives in El Alto in an adobe house. He makes a living sewing clothing (jackets and coats), mainly out of fabric and fiber.

He lives in the house of his parents, located in El Alto. He needs a loan to pay for a course that will help him improve the quality of his work, in other words, he wants to do a refresher course. Efrain is the only one who economically contributes in his home.

loans.use: pay for a course that will help him improve the quality of his work.

loans.name: Jose Mercedes

texts.es:
José, tiene una familia formada por su esposa y dos hijos de 10 y 13 años de edad, actualmente solo dependen tres personas económicamente de él; aprendió de su padre a trabajar en el campo, tiene más de 25 años de cultivar maíz, frijol y café como una forma de tener ingresos para cubrir las necesidades básicas de su familia, no tiene un horario establecido para realizar sus actividades.
Necesita capital para comprar abono, insecticidas, herbicidas y semilla, con lo que limpiara el terreno en donde cultiva y mejora la calidad de sus granos, espera tener más ingresos con los que seguirá cuidando del bienestar familiar y cumpliendo con el pago de sus deudas.
Su aspiración es lograr una buena inversión para ampliar su negocio y asegurar un futuro más confortable para su familia.
texts.en:
José has a family made up of his wife and two children, aged 10 and 13. Currently, only three people depend upon him economically. He learned from his father how to work in the field. He has been growing corn, beans and coffee for more than 25 years as a form of having income to cover the basic needs of his family. He doesn't have an established schedule to carry out his activities.

He needs capital to buy fertilizer, insecticides, herbicides and seeds, with which he will clean the land where he cultivates and improves the quality of his grains. He hopes to have more income with which he will continue caring for the wellbeing of the family and fulfilling the payment of his debts. His aspiration is to achieve a good investment to grow his business and assure a more comfortable future for his family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, insecticides, herbicides and seeds.

loans.name: Victoria Carmelina

texts.es:
Victoria, es una joven soltera, vive con su mamá; en busca de brindar apoyo económico para cancelar los gastos de su hogar, inicio desde hace varios años junto a su madre la venta de pupusas, no han tenido dificultades para administrar su negocio.
El capital que está solicitando lo invertirá en la compra de quesillo, chicharrón, harina, maíz, aceite, aderezos, bebidas, repollo, tomates y bolsas.  Tendrá abastecido su negocio para seguir trabajando y cubriendo la demanda de sus clientes. Espera que los resultados de la inversión sean positivos y que pueda finalizar su deuda.
Su visión es tener su propio local para ofertar otro tipo de productos que sean de ayuda para atraer más clientes y mejorar su situación económica.
texts.en:
Victoria is a single young woman, she lives with her mother. In search of bringing economic support to pay for the expenses of her home, she started selling pupusas alongside her mother several years ago. They haven't had difficulties in running their business.

She will invest the capital that she is applying for in the purchase of cheese, pork cracklings, flour, corn, oil, dressings, drinks, cabbage, tomatoes and bags. She will have her business stocked to continue working and covering the demand of her customers. She hopes that the results of the investment will be positive and that she will be able to pay off her debt.

Her vision is to have her own storefront to offer other types of products that help to attract more customers and improve her economic situation.

loans.use: to buy cheese, pork cracklings, flour, corn, oil, dressings, drinks, cabbage, tomatoes and bags.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Mirna Del Carmen

texts.es:
Mirna, se dedica a vender diversos cosméticos, lociones, desodorantes, etc., lo hace desde hace tres años con el apoyo de su hija mayor, trabaja todos los días de 6:0 a.m.  hasta  2:00 p.m., su negocio nace con el objetivo de aportar en los gastos de su hogar; Mirna vive en compañía de su compañero de vida y sus dos hijas.
Utilizará el crédito para comprar lociones, cremas corporales, labiales, polvos, papel higiénico, shampoos, talcos, desodorantes, jabones, etc., con está mercadería tendrá a disposición de sus clientes lo que necesitan, espera tener mejores ganancias, para cancelar su préstamo.
Su aspiración es tener un negocio más rentable para brindar mejores condiciones de vida a su familia.
texts.en:
Mirna works selling a variety of cosmetics, lotions deodorants, etc. She has been doing this for the past 3 years with the help of her oldest daughter. She works every day from 6 am until 2 pm. Her business was born out of the need to help with the household expenses. Mirna lives in the company of her life companion and her two daughters.

She will use the loan to buy lotion, body cream, lipstick, powder, toilet paper, shampoo, talc, deodorant, soap, etc. With this merchandise she can offer her clients what they need. She hopes to receive more income so she can pay off the loan. Her dream is to have a more profitable business to provide better living conditions for her family.

loans.use: to buy lotion, body cream, lipstick, powder, toilet paper, shampoo, talc, deodorant, soap, etc.

loans.name: Maira Evelin

texts.es:
Maira, es casada, junto a su esposo son responsables de criar a sus hijos y darles lo necesario para subsistir, todos viven juntos; trabaja todos los días de tres de la tarde a nueve  de la noche en la elaboración y venta de pupusas, el cual está ubicado en su vivienda, es así como obtiene ingresos económicos para cubrir parte de los gastos de su familia.
Invertirá en la compra de maíz, aceite, quesillo, tomates, repollo, aderezos, jugos, gaseosas y chicharrón, teniendo los materiales necesarios para la venta seguirá trabajando y dando un  buen servicio a sus clientes, espera estabilizarse económicamente  y cumplir con sus compromisos económicos.
Su sueño es tener un restaurante en el que pueda ofrecer variedad de comida y mejorar su calidad de vida familiar.
texts.en:
Maira is married. Along with her husband, they are responsible for raising their two children and giving them what's necessary for subsistence. They all live together; they work every day from three in the afternoon to nine at night making and selling pupusas. This is located in her home; this is how she obtains economic income to cover part of the family's expenses.

She will invest in the purchase of corn, oil, cheese, tomatoes, cabbage, dressings, juice, soda and pork cracklings. Having the necessary materials for sale, she will continue working and giving good service to her customers; she hopes to stabilize herself economically and fulfill her economic commitments. Her dream is to have a restaurant where she can offer a variety of food and improve her family quality of life.

loans.use: to buy corn, oil, cheese, tomatoes, cabbage, dressings, juice, soda and pork cracklings.

loans.name: Fanny Lorena

texts.es: Con 39  años de edad Fanny se dedica a la  venta ambulante de ropa para dama y caballero, Fanny también trabaja a medio tiempo de vendedora en una tienda de víveres, Fanny vive con su esposo y sus 2 hijos de 15 y 5 años de edad, Fanny comenta que el negocio de venta de ropa lo emprendió con FODEMI y que por este motivo está muy agradecida ya que así logra tener un ingreso mas para sacar adelante a sus hijos, Fanny va a invertir el crédito en la compra de mercadería en ropa para ofrecerle a sus clientes, ella aspira en un futuro comprarse una casita ya que en la actualidad vive en la casa de su suegra.
texts.en:
With 39 years of age, Fanny works as a street vendor of women and men's clothing. Fanny also works part time as a saleswoman in a food store. Fanny lives with her husband and their 2 children, ages 15 and 5. Fanny comments that she undertook the clothing sale business with FODEMI and, for this reason, she is very thankful since she achieves having more income to get her children ahead. 

Fanny will invest the loan in the purchase of clothing merchandise to offer to her customers. She aspires to buy herself a house in the future since currently, she lives in the house of her stepmother.

loans.use: to buy clothing.

loans.name: Sonia Raquel

texts.es:
Sonia, se dedica a la venta de maricos, se traslada 4 veces por semana a la capital del país a vender sus productos, ya tiene tres años de hacer esta actividad, lo aprendió de su madre quien también vende mariscos pero de forma separada; Sonia es soltera, vive con su madre, ambas se dividen los gastos de su hogar.
El financiamiento que solicita lo invertirá en la compra 3 qq de camarones, variedad de pescado y otros moluscos, y el resto lo utilizara para abastecer su negocio cada vez que sea necesario, se mantendrá trabajando por un largo tiempo y teniendo los ingresos que necesita para salir adelante.
Su sueño es lograr tener un negocio autosuficiente y apoyar a su familia.
texts.en:
Sonia works selling seafood. She travels 4 times a week to the capital of the country to sell her products. She has been doing this business for three years. She learned from her mother who also sold seafood but on her own. Sonia is single and lives with her mother. They share the living expenses.

The loan will be used to buy 3 quintals of shrimp, a variety of fish and other mollusks. The rest of the loan she will use to stock her business as needed. This will maintain her working for a long time and give her the income she needs to get ahead. Her dream is to have a sustainable business and support her family.

loans.use: to buy shrimp, a variety of fish and other mollusks.

loans.name: Sandra Elizabeth

texts.es: Sandra se dedica 7 años a su negocio que es una farmacia, Sandra vive con sus padres y le prestan un cuarto de su casa para que exhiba sus productos, Sandra también trabaja de educadora familiar de casa en casa, Sandra solicita el crédito para invertir en productos farmacéuticos, Sandra es una joven trabajadora que aspira comprarse una casa para poner su local propio y de esta manera mejorar su calidad de vida.
texts.en: Sandra has been running her business which is a pharmacy for 7 years. Sandra lives with her parents and they let her use a room in the house to display her products. Sandra also works as a family educator from house to house. Sandra is requesting a loan to invest in pharmaceutical products.Sandra is a young worker who aspires to buy her own house so that she can set up her own store and in this way improve her quality of living.

loans.use: to buy pharmaceuticals.

loans.name: Sandra

texts.en:
Sandra, a 20-year-old businesswoman, is single and has one child. She lives in the Nyanga District of Zimbabwe. Sandra successfully runs a farming project, growing potatoes, tomatoes, cabbages and onions. She also volunteers at the local school every week as a Learner Guide, assisting students with their studies.

Sandra intends to use this Kiva loan to expand her business by buying fertilizer and herbicides and to boost her production and sales volume. She hopes to supply more vegetables in her community and earn enough profits to care for herself and her child.

loans.use: to purchase farming supplies

loans.name: Abirami Shg-Kathiramangalam Group

texts.en:
People Action for Transformation is the local NGO. They formed the Abirami Self Help Group, which contain five members from the same locality. 

Meena is the leader of the Abirami Self help group and she lives in Kathiramangalam village. Meena lives in her own house with her husband Rajkumar. Her husband is a small farmer. He works as on daily wage basis. 

Meena and the other members want to purchase a smokeless stove manufactured by Greenway Grameen Infra Pvt, Ltd. It costs 1,400 INR. It is better than their traditional mud stove. Apart from providing a better cooking environment, the stove is easy to use and maintain, and can be used with indigenous biomass as fuel.

These women are looking forward to a healthier life.

loans.use: to buy a smokeless stove

loans.name: Mutumarriamman Shg-Kathiramangalam Group

texts.en:
Shanti is the leader of the Mutumarriamman Self Help Group, which is managed by the local NGO People Action for Transformation (PAT) in Tamil Nadu. Shanti lives in Kathiramangalam village with her children and husband in her own house. Her husband, Rajendran, is a farmer and works on a daily wage basis in their village. She has taken loans from PAT previously and repaid them on time.

Shanti and the other members are requesting a loan to purchase a smokeless stove, which is manufactured by Greenway Grameen Infra Pvt, Ltd. It costs 1,400 INR. A smokeless stove emits less carbon dioxide, which reduces smoke. Traditional stoves consume more time and money. The smokeless stove is highly efficient and designed for long-term use. This will allow a reduction in problems related to health, deforestation and climate change.

loans.use: to buy a smokeless stove

loans.name: Ulises Gabriel

texts.es: Ulises Gabriel, tiene la edad  de 54 años, está casado,  vive con su esposa y sus hijos los cuales su mayor prioridad. Con su crédito pretende hacer la compra de fertilizantes y otros productos para aplicarle al cultivo de frijol y así que tenga un buen desarrollo y cosecha, además pagar mano de obra para la aplicación de los productos y asistencia de la plantación una vez que tenga desarrollo, y de esta manera asegurarse de realizar un buen trabajo. Lo que pretende es aprovechar las buenas condiciones de clima y suelo que cuenta la zona para este cultivo, y también poner en práctica la experiencia de varios años en el manejo de granos básicos. Además de poder comprar los mejores productos y de mejor calidad para que su plantación tenga un buen desarrollo y sanidad al igual que una cosecha adecuada, y tener a corto plazo una producción importante. Con el ingreso de la cosecha que espera obtener quiere utilizarla en el bienestar y estudio de su familia y cumplir con algunas metas familiares y seguir invirtiendo más en los cultivos. Es el primer  préstamo que  recibido de FUDECOSUR. Él no había tenido antes otros préstamos en bancos estatales, pero FUDECOSUR le ha brindado el préstamo con mayores facilidades y la tasa de intereses mucho más baja.
texts.en: Ulises Gabriel is 54 years old. He is married and he lives with his wife and his children who are his top priority. With his loan he intends to complete the purchase of fertilizers and other products to apply to a crop of beans so he can achieve good growth and a good harvest. In addition, he will pay for manual labor to apply these products and to help with the maintenance once he has growing plants and this way he will ensure that it will be a job well done. He intends to take advantage of the good climate conditions and soil that this area has for this type of crop. He also will put into practice his various years of experience growing basic grains. Moreover, with this loan he is able to purchase the best products of the highest quality so that his plants will grow well, be healthy, become a proper crop and quickly produce a large production. He wants to use the earnings from the harvest that he hopes to have for the wellbeing and schooling of his family, to accomplish some family goals and to continue investing more in his crops. This is the first loan that he has received from Fudecosur. He has not received other loans before from state banks, but Fudecosur has provided this loan with greater ease and a much lower interest rate.

loans.use: to plant and care for beans.

loans.name: Mishell Katherine

texts.es: Katherine es una señora que le gusta mucho trabajar para ayudar a su esposo en los gastos de su hogar, Katherine tiene 2 hijos, de 5 y 7 años de edad y se encuentra estudiando, ella trabaja haciendo quesos y en lo que resta del día  se dedica a la venta de ropa juntamente con su esposo, con el crédito Katherine va a comprar mercadería en ropa  y de este negocio aspira poder ahorrar y en algún tiempo tener casa propia ya que en la actualidad vive en la casa de sus padres.
texts.en: Katherine is a woman who likes to work a lot to help her husband with household expenses. Katherine has 2 children who are 5 and 7 years old. They are in school. She makes cheese and sells clothing alongside her husband. With the loan, she is going to buy clothing. Through this business, she hopes to save money and buy her own home since she currently lives in her parents' house.

loans.use: to buy clothes

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is 24 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, with one of them currently in school. For the past three years, Mariam has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells shoes. 

To help expand her business, Mariam has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more shoes to sell, and will help Mariam to generate greater profits and take good care of her family's basic needs. Mariam hopes that in the future, she will be able to buy a plot of land and build a house. 

Mariam is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more shoes to sell.

loans.name: Rommana

texts.en:
Rommana is a 23-year-old businesswoman who is married with one child. She lives in the Nyanga District of Zimbabwe. She is successfully operating a farm, growing and selling tobacco, tomatoes, and onions. She also volunteers at the local school as a Learner Guide teaching life skills classes.

With the requested loan, she intends to make bulk purchases of farming supplies such as fertilizers, seeds, and herbicides to boost production and sales volume. With the additional profits, she hopes to expand into a larger farming enterprise and provide a higher standard of living for her family.

loans.use: to make bulk purchases of farming supplies.

loans.name: Durgai Shg-Kallur Group

texts.en:
The Durgai Self Help Group consists of five members from Kallur village, Tanjore district. It is managed by the local NGO, People Action for Transformation (PAT) in Tamil Nadu, India. 

Selvi is the group leader. She lives in her own house with two children and her husband, Mahenthiran. Her husband is a carpenter. Selvi has taken loans from the PAT for the last seven years and she has repaid the loan amount on time. Selvi needs a loan to purchase a smokeless stove, which is manufactured by the Greenway Grameen Infra Pvt, Ltd. The traditional stoves have a high tendency to cause respiratory problems in many households as it emits carbon dioxide. The smokeless stove reduces the risk of respiratory diseases, emits less smoke and provides healthier living conditions.

Along with Selvi, the other members of the group are requesting a loan to purchase smokeless stove.

loans.use: to buy a smokeless stove

loans.name: Gangai Shg-Keelakattur Group

texts.en:
Gangai Self Help Group is managed by the local NGO, People Action for Transformation (PAT) in Tamil Nadu, India.  They help people in improve their livelihood. Maragatham is the leader of the group, which contains 12 more members from Keelakattur village, Tanjore district.

Maragatham lives with her children and husband, Anbazhagan. Her husband is a small farmer who works for daily wages. Maragatham has previously taken loans from the PAT for improving her economic conditions and has regularly repaid the loans on time.

Maragatham and the other members of the group want to buy a smokeless stove to have a healthy life. A smokeless stove is economical and greatly reduces carbon emissions, limiting the toxic and hazardous effects of indoor pollution.

loans.use: to buy a smokeless stove

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase large quantities of skirts, shoes, pants, and tops to sell at her shop.

loans.name: Previous

texts.en:
Previous is a 26-year-old married mother of two from the Guruve District of Zimbabwe. She serves as a peer educator in her community and a volunteer Camfed Learner Guide at the local secondary school. 

Previous and her husband have been operating a grocery shop for the past year. This is the family's only source of income. 

Previous sells sugar, rice, tea, cooking oil, potato chips, stationary and sanitary wear in her shop. With this Kiva loan, she would like to make bulk purchases of these items to reduce her costs and increase her profits and sales.

loans.use: To make bulk purchases of  sugar, rice, tea, cooking oil, potato chips and other items for her grocery shop.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a 20-year-old entrepreneur from the Guruve District of Zimbabwe. She runs a poultry business to support her family and she is happy to feed her community. In her spare time, she is a volunteer Camfed Learner Guide, working with students to improve their studying skills. 

Judith is seeking a Kiva loan to buy large quantities of broiler chicks, feed, and chemicals to meet the demands of her customers. She will use the profits from her business to improve her standard of living and become financially self-sufficient.

loans.use: To buy more broiler chicks, feed, and chemicals.

loans.name: Mesaid

texts.en:
This is Mesaid. She previously accessed a loan that she used for her business. Her earnings were a big help for her personal, household, and business expenditures.

She is requesting for a loan to purchase wheat flour, maize flour, rice, and beans for resale. She appreciates Kiva for their financial support..

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, maize flour, rice, and beans for resale.

loans.name: Allison Marcela

texts.es:
Allison es una joven emprendedora, tiene 20 años de edad, es soltera y vive en Lurin junto a su familia.
Es una joven con muchas ganas de salir adelante. Estudia la carrera universitaria de Arquitectura en una Universidad de la zona donde vive, es una joven brillante e inteligente.
Desde hace más de 2 años se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza, accesorios, ropa y artículos de bazar. Con mucho esfuerzo y dedicación logró comprar tres vitrinas pequeñas para poder exhibir sus productos en su domicilio.
Su mayor motivación en la vida es su familia, es por ello que lucha día a día para poder apoyarlos. A pesar de ser una persona muy joven tiene muchos proyectos en mente que le gustaría ejecutar más adelante.
Allison está agradecida con los prestamistas Kiva porque con el apoyo que le han brindado ella podrá comprar mercadería para poder implementar su negocio y de esta manera tener mayores productos para ofrecer. Con esto ella seguirá esforzándose para mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia y más adelante poder cumplir una de sus mayores metas: "Ampliar su negocio".
texts.en:
Allison is a young entrepreneur. She is 20 years old. She is single and lives in Lurin with her family. She is a young woman with the desire to get ahead. She is an architecture major in a university in the area where she lives. She is a brilliant and intelligent young woman. 

For more than 2 years, she has sold beauty products, accessories, clothing, and keepsakes. With a lot of effort and dedication, she has been able to buy three small showcases to exhibit her products in her home. She is motivated by her family. For them, she works hard every day. In spite of being young, she has a lot of ideas that she would like the realize in the future. 

Allison is thankful for the Kiva investors because she can buy merchandise and offer more products in her store with their support. With it, she will also be able to continue fighting to improve her family's quality-of-life and eventually reach another one of her biggest goals: expanding her store.

loans.use: to buy merchandise to stock her cosmetics store.

loans.name: Main De Dieu (2) Group

texts.en:
Sylvestre is a young entrepreneur from Brazzaville, the Republic of Congo, who makes and sells smoked fish out of his home. At home he supports his wife and 2-year-old child in addition to two little brothers. In order to help increase his business activity, Sylvestre joined HOPE Congo earlier this year, becoming a member of the community bank group MAIN DE DIEU (2). 

Sylvestre leads a sub-group of ten other micro-entrepreneurs within MAIN DE DIEU (2) and is currently on his second loan cycle with HOPE Congo. Now Sylvestre would like to take out a small loan of 300,000 XAF (Central African CFA francs) in order to buy more fish. In the future, he hopes to expand his business and one day be able to save enough money to build his family their own home.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Sakthi Shg-Kottairyur Group

texts.en:
Saritha is the leader of the Sakthi Self Help Group, which is managed by the local NGO, People Action for Transformation (PAT) in Tamil Nadu, India. She lives in Kottairyur village, Tanjore district. Saritha and her family live in their own house. She has three children. Her husband, Arumugam, is a small marginal farmer who works on a daily wage basis.
 
Saritha wants to purchase a smokeless stove, which will save her time and money. The smokeless stove prevents the risk of getting respiratory diseases from the smoke emitted. Saritha and the other members of the group are requesting a loan for a healthier life.

loans.use: to buy a smokeless stove

loans.name: Amman Shg-Aariyapadaiveedu Group

texts.en:
Lalitha is 42 years old and the leader of the Amman Self Help Group, which is managed by the local NGO, People Action for Transformation (PAT) in Tamil Nadu. Lalitha lives in Aariyapadaiveedu village, Tanjore district with her children and husband in her own house. Her husband, Ravi, is a farmer who works on a daily wage basis. 

Lalitha needs a loan to purchase a smokeless stove, which is efficient, clean, and easy for daily use for cooking. The traditional stove creates environmental hazards such as deforestation. Smokeless stoves reduce the risk of respiratory illness as they emit much less smoke. 

Along with Lalitha, the other members are requesting a loan to purchase a smokeless stove.

loans.use: to buy a smokeless stove

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is 22 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has two children with one of them currently in school. For the past three years, Lydia has been working hard to manage her poultry business, which sells chickens.

To help expand her business, Lydia has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more chickens and feed, and will help Lydia to generate greater profits and increase her capital more. Lydia hopes that in the future she will be able to build a house of her own.

Lydia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more chickens and feed

loans.name: Beaulah

texts.en: Beaulah is an 18-year-old businesswoman living in the Kwekwe District of Zimbabwe. Beaulah has been selling ladies’ skirts, blouses, blue jeans, shoes and children’s clothes at a flea market for six months now. When she is not working at her flea market stand, Beaulah volunteers helping the elderly and the sick together with the Cama members of her community. With the requested loan from Kiva, she intends to purchase clothes in bulk to boost her sales and profits. With additional profits she hopes to pay fees for her siblings.

loans.use: to purchase clothes in bulk

loans.name: Takunda

texts.en: Takunda is 18 years old and lives in the Guruve District of Zimbabwe. She volunteers in the local school as a Camfed Learner Guide and runs a small business. Takunda rents a stall  at the local market and sells shirts, dresses, shoes and jackets. She really loves her business and would like to increase her sales volume and expand the business. She believes that if she receives the Kiva loan her business will improve considerably. Takunda is seeking a Kiva loan so that she can purchase more shirts, dresses, shoes and jackets to increase her stock. She intends to use the proceeds to improve her standard of living and hopefully create employment opportunities for people in her community if the business continues to thrive.

loans.use: To purchase more shirts, dresses, shoes and jackets to increase her stock.

loans.name: Malar Shg-Perumandi Group

texts.en:
Padmavathi is the leader of the Malar Self Help Group, which is managed by the local NGO, People Action for Transformation (PAT) in Tamil Nadu. Padmavathi lives in Perumandi village, Tanjore district. She is 50 years old and lives in her own house with her children and husband, Emayavarman. Padmavathi has taken loans from the PAT previously and repaid them on time. She has taken loans to improve her livelihood and for the cultivation of paddy, sugar cane, and ragi etc.
 
Padmavathi wants to buy a smokeless stove, which is better than the traditional stove. The latter emits a lot of carbon dioxide and creates health and environmental problems. The smokeless stove emits less smoke, reduces the risk of respiratory diseases and is clean and easy to use.

Along with Padmavathi, the other members are requesting a loan to purchase a smokeless stove to lead a healthier life.

loans.use: to buy a smokeless stove

loans.name: Trish

texts.en:
Trish is a 21-year-old businesswoman who is married with one child. She lives in the Nyanga District of Zimbabwe. Trish has been successfully operating a poultry business for over a year and has employed one worker to assist her. She also volunteers at the local school as a Learner Guide assisting students with their studies.

With a Kiva loan, she intends to make bulk purchases of broiler chicks, along with the feed and supplies needed to raise them. With the additional profits she hopes to expand her business, create more employment opportunities and provide a higher standard of living for her family.

loans.use: to purchase chicks and chick feed

loans.name: Elisa Maria

texts.es: Elisa vive en una pequeña ciudad de  la provincia del Carchi, donde tiene su negocio de pañales y de otros productos para el aseo personal, Elisa tiene 63 años de edad y son 2 años de lo que se dedica a  su negocio, Elisa vive con su esposo que es jornalero, con un cuñado que es discapacitado y es Elisa quien le cuida y le alimenta, y con una hija que es soltera y los otros 4 hijos ya viven aparte, el crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de mercadería en pañales y otros productos para venderlos en su negocio, ella aspira salir adelante y en el futuro comprar un tractor para utilizarlo como herramienta de trabajo.
texts.en: Elisa lives in a little city in the province of Carchi, where she has her business of selling diapers and other personal care products. Elisa is 63 years old and she has had her business for 2 years. Elisa lives with her husband, who is a day laborer, and with a brother-in-law who is disabled. It is Elisa who cares for him and feeds him. She also lives with a daughter who is single, and her other four children already live elsewhere. She is going to invest the loan in the purchase of merchandise such as diapers and other products to sell in her business. She hopes to get ahead and in the future to buy a tractor to use a work tool.

loans.use: to buy diapers to sell in her business

loans.name: Top Class Group

texts.en:
Top Class is a group of seven people, whose members live in the same neighborhood. They are into cosmetics, ladies' bags, wigs, lining, slippers, canned beef, eggs, noodles, and tailoring.

The representative for the group, Margaret, is 38 years old and is married with children. Margaret has had little schooling. For the past nine years, she has been running a business selling cosmetics. She gets her supplies from one of Ghana's markets. In their quest for customer satisfaction, Margaret and the other members of the Top class group are requesting a third loan. This loan will help them respond better to customer requests and make more profits. All previous loans have been fully repaid.

loans.use: to buy more cosmetics for customers.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a hardworking, enterprising woman. She is a married mother of one child who is still underage. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is on food.

Fatuma cooks fried potatoes and sells them to neighbours and passersby. She cites seasonality as her major challenge.

With this loan, she wants to purchase a sack of potatoes and cooking oil. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and establish a restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase a sack of potatoes and cooking oil.

loans.name: Nanette

texts.en:
Nanette is a 19-year-old businesswoman from the Guruve District of Zimbabwe. Along with being a volunteer Camfed Learner Guide, she rents a small shop where she sells groceries such as cooking oil, sugar, salt, maize-meal (ground maize), sugar beans, matemba (dried fish), biscuits, sweets, and stationery. Nanette started the business at her homestead last year and she is very pleased with how far she has come. 

Nanette would like to use the Kiva loan to expand her business by increasing her stocks. She hopes to grow her business even more and increase its profitability to better provide for her family’s needs. She is also interested in doing her part to create more employment opportunities in her community.

loans.use: to expand her business by increasing her stocks.

loans.name: Main De Dieu (1) Group

texts.en:
Augustine is a mother of eight children, five of whom she is still putting through school. To help take care of her family, Augustine makes and sells manioc, a traditional Congolese food made from cassava root and eaten with most meals. 

An extremely labour-intensive but profitable business, Augustine hopes to continue her manioc-making trade in the future. To continue to do so, she would like to take out a loan for 300,000 Congolese francs from HOPE Congo to purchase additional cassava root.

Augustine joined HOPE Congo earlier this year and is a member of the community bank group MAIN DE DIEU (1). She leads a subgroup of 10 other micro-entrepreneurs in Brazzaville, the Republic of Congo. 

In the future, Augustine hopes to be able to build her own home on a piece of land that she owns, saving up little by little from her business profits. She also dreams for her children, praying that they will all be able to finish school well.

loans.use: to purchase additional cassava root

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is 17 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past 3 years, Betty has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells firewood. 

To help expand her business, Betty has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more firewood for sale, and will help Betty to generate greater profits and improve more on her business and her family's standard of living. Betty hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Betty is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more firewood for sale

loans.name: Oscar Rene

texts.es:
Oscar, vive junto a su madre y sus hermanos, es casado; como una forma de tener ingresos con los cueles cubre sus gastos personales y aporta para los gastos familiares realiza el cultivo de granos básicos (maíz, maicillo y frijol) y hace trabajos de albañilería, Oscar estuvo en el extranjero y regreso al país en busca de trabajar en un negocio propio para superarse mejor.
Invertirá en la compra de abono, semilla, fertilizantes, plaguicidas, fertilizantes e insecticidas, con la ayuda de estos insumos le dará a sus cultivos un mejor trato, con lo que espera tener mejores ingresos que le ayuden a iniciar a trabajar en la crianza de cerdos.
Su anhelo es ir ampliando poco a poco su negocio para seguir teniendo ingresos con los que apoyará a su familia y resarcirá su deuda.
texts.en:
Oscar lives with his mother and his siblings. He is married. As a way of having income with which he can cover his personal expenses and contribute to the family expenses, he raises basic grains (corn, sorghum, and beans) and does work as a mason. Oscar was abroad, and he came back to the country in search of work in a business of his own in order to better himself.

He will invest in the purchase of compost, seeds, fertilizers, pesticides, and insecticides. With the help of these supplies, he will give his crops better treatment, with which he hopes to have better income that will help him to begin to raise pigs.

His goal is to expand his business little by little in order to continue having income with which he will help his family and pay off his debt.

loans.use: to buy compost, seeds, fertilizers, pesticides, and insecticides

loans.name: White 2 (2) Group

texts.en:
Rubin runs a small butcher’s shop and video game room in Brazzaville, the Republic of Congo. Working to support his three children, Rubin has been running his business activities for the past two years, battling the frequent power outages of Brazzaville. In order to improve his businesses and increase his means of income, Rubin joined HOPE Congo in the community bank group White 2 (2). 

Rubin is the leader of a small group of 11 other micro-entrepreneurs in Brazzaville, and would like to take out his first small loan of 250,000 XAF (Central African CFA francs), the local currency. With this loan, Rubin will be able to purchase additional chicken, beef, and other meats for his butcher’s shop and add a small drinks area to his video game room. He gains customers by offering a warm and welcoming atmosphere and building friendships with his neighbors.

In the future, Rubin would like to grow his business to include a walk-in freezer so that he can increase his capacity to keep meat fresh. Through the proceeds from his businesses, Rubin hope to be able to support his children and put all of them through school.

loans.use: to be able to purchase additional chicken, beef, and other meats for his butcher's shop and add a small drinks area to his video game room.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to repair his truck, which allows him to work in transportation.

loans.name: Monica

texts.es:
La socia  Monica  se sigue dedicando al negocio de artesania, la socia vende  tejidos, chompas, mantas y telares, la socia vende diferentes tejidos, la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 7:00 p.m,la socia ya tiene 8 años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es ampliar el negocio de venta de tejidos y telares. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar tejidos, chompas y telares.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Communal bank member Monica continues working in her handicrafts business. She sells knitted items, sweaters, blankets, and weavings. She sells different types of knitted items. She works from 8:00 am to 7:00 pm. She has already had this business for 8 years, and it is going very well for her. Her dream is to expand her business of selling knitted items and weavings. She is applying for the loan to buy knitted items, sweaters, and weavings.

She is happy about the loan and promises to make her payments.

loans.use: to buy knitted items, sweaters, and weavings to sell

loans.name: Fortunate

texts.en:
Fortunate is a 21-year-old businesswoman who is currently single and lives in the Nyanga District of Zimbabwe. She has been successfully operating a business of buying and selling clothes, shoes, cosmetics, and bags. She has also been volunteering at the local school as a Learner Guide, supporting students with their studies.

With a Kiva loan, Fortunate intends to make bulk purchases of more clothing and shoes. This will increase her profit margins and help her supply more goods to her community. She hopes to create employment in her community and increase her income to become financially independent.

loans.use: to make bulk purchases of more clothing and shoes.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a 25-year-old businesswoman who is married with one child and lives in the Nyanga District of Zimbabwe. She has been successfully operating a farming business for over a year, where she is growing beans, cabbage, and tomatoes. She volunteers every week at the local school as a Learner Guide, assisting students with their studies.

With the requested loan, she intends to buy more seeds, fertilizers, herbicides, and irrigation pipes to expand her business. She hopes to create more employment in her community, to supply more vegetables, and to improve the living standard of her family.

loans.use: to purchase farming supplies.

loans.name: Kurinji Shg-Perumandi Group

texts.en:
Ladha is 48 years old and lives in her own house with her two children and husband, Chinnathambi. Her husband is a snacks vendor. They live in a village, Perumandi, in Tanjore district.

Ladha is the leader of the Kurinji Self-Help Group, which is formed by a local NGO, People's Action for Transformation (PAT), in Tamil Nadu. The NGO majorly works to improve the livelihood of the people in that region.

Ladha and the other members are requesting a loan to purchase a smokeless stove, which emits much less smoke and is better than the traditional mud stove. The smokeless stove is designed for daily use and is more efficient and clean. It promotes healthier lifestyles by limiting the toxic and hazardous effects of indoor pollution.

loans.use: to buy a smokeless stove.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es:
La socia  Nancy se sigue dedicando al negocio de bazar, la socia vende regalos y adornos, la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 6:00 p.m,la socia ya tiene varios años en este negocio y el va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es ampliar el negocio de venta de bazar. La socia solicita el  credito para comprar adornos y peluches.

 La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Communal bank member Nancy continues to work in her bazaar business. She sells gifts and decorations. She works from 8:00 am to 6:00 pm. She has been in this business for a number of years, and it is going very well. Her dream is to expand her bazaar sales business. She is applying for the loan to buy decorations and stuffed toys.

She is happy about the loan and promises to make her payments.

loans.use: to buy decorations and stuffed toys

loans.name: Bernardatte

texts.en:
Bernardatte is 36 years old and lives in the town of Hoima in the Hoima region of Uganda. She has four children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past ten years, Bernardatte has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Bernardatte has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes for sale, and will help Bernardatte to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. She hopes that in the future she will be able to develop her plot of land and build rental houses. 

Bernardatte is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Bernardatte who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for sale.

loans.name: Precious

texts.en:
Precious is a 19-year-old businesswoman who lives in the Kwekwe District of Zimbabwe. With help from other Cama members on the management of business, she has been successfully operating a flea market for the past eight months. Precious also volunteers in schools by assisting in cleaning the school toilets, and she is also a Learner Guide who teaches students life skills. 

With the requested loan, she intends to purchase more quality and fashionable clothes to boost her sales and profits. With increased profits she intends to help in the paying of fees for her siblings.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Jathimalli Shg Group

texts.en:
Forty-two-year-old Sumathi is leader of the Jathimalli Self-Help Group, which is formed by the local NGO, People’s Action for Transformation (PAT), in Tamil Nadu. Sumathi and her family live in their own house. Her husband, Kumar, is an agricultural farmer. She has been taking loans from the PAT to improve the economic condition of the family and always repaid on time.

Sumathi and the other members of the group are requesting a loan to buy smokeless stoves manufactured by the Greenway Grameen Infra Pvt., Ltd. The traditional stove is a kitchen killer, which emits a lot of carbon dioxide and leads to stinging eyes, scratchy throats and soot-covered walls. The smokeless stove is better than traditional stoves, as it reduces health-related risks and improves quality of life.

loans.use: to buy a smokeless stove.

loans.name: Hazel

texts.en:
Hazel is a 20-year-old single businesswoman who lives in the Kwekwe District of Zimbabwe. She has been successfully running a flea market for eight months now. She got the idea of starting a business from other Cama members in her district. Cama is a network of Camfed alumnae. Hazel volunteers her spare time fetching water during the construction of a classroom and renovations. 

With the requested loan, she intends to purchase good quality clothing in bulk from wholesalers so as to enjoy low purchasing costs and boost sales and profits. With additional profits, she hopes to pay fees for her siblings.

loans.use: to sell more clothes.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is a 20-year-old businesswoman. She is single and lives in the Nyanga District of Zimbabwe. She has been successfully running a farming business, growing potatoes and raising chickens. She also volunteers as a Learner Guide at the local school to support students with their studies.

With a Kiva loan, Monica intends to make bulk purchases of fertilizer and potato seeds to boost her profits. With the additional profits, she hopes to create employment in her community, provide for her family, and become financially independent.

loans.use: to purchase farming supplies.

loans.name: Nelson

texts.es:
El socio Nelson se dedica al negocio de transporte de carga, el socio lleva carga como frutas, animales y verduras a diferentes lugares, el socio trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 10:00 p.m,el socio ya tiene 6 años en este negocio y le va muy bien el sueño del socio es comprarse un carro nuevo. El socio solicita el crédito para comprar llantas para su transporte de carga.

El socio está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Communal bank member Nelson works in the business of transporting cargo. He carries cargo such as fruits, animals, and vegetables to different places. He works from 8:00 am to 10:00 pm. He has already been in this business for 6 years, and it is going very well for him. His dream is to buy a new car. He is applying for the loan to buy tires for his cargo transport.

He is happy about the loan and promises to make his payments.

loans.use: to buy tires for his cargo transport.

loans.name: Sumangali Shg-Devanchery Group

texts.en:
Sumangali Self-Help Group is managed by the local NGO, People’s Action for Transformation (PAT).  This NGO helps people improve their livelihood in Tamil Nadu. 

Jerinabegam is the leader of this group, which contains seven more members. She lives in Devanchery village, Tanjore district, in her own house with her husband and children. Her husband, Syedabulkhadar, runs a mutton stall in the village. 

Jerinabegam is a regular customer of the PAT. She has been taking loans for the last seven years, and has repaid the loans on time.

Jerinabegam wants to purchase a smokeless stove, which is manufactured by Greenway Grameen Infra Pvt., Ltd. Its cost is 1,400 INR. It is designed for daily use. The traditional stoves produce more smoke and are called a kitchen killer. The smokeless stove emits less carbon dioxide and prevents household risk. It also promotes healthier lifestyles by limiting the toxic and hazardous effects of indoor pollution.

Jerinabegam and the other members are requesting a loan to purchase a smokeless stove to give a healthier life to their families.

loans.use: to buy a smokeless stove.

loans.name: Matondo (1) Group

texts.en:
Armel is a member of the community bank group Matondo (1), and the leader of a subgroup of four other micro-entrepreneurs in Brazzaville, the Republic of Congo. Armel owns a small pharmacy shop in his neighborhood as well as a small drink stand. As a member of Matondo (1), Armel has taken out several small loans to keep investing in his business. He is now on his seventh loan cycle with HOPE Congo and would like to take out a loan of 700,000 XAF (Central African CFA francs) to invest in his various activities. 

With this money, Armel will purchase additional pharmaceutical items to sell at his shop, as well as drinks for his drink business and phone cards to sell at his new phone cabinet. All of these small businesses help Armel to support his family of two children, his wife, and his younger brother’s schooling. After starting with just a small table selling miscellaneous items, Armel is now bursting with ideas for the future and hopes to eventually move on to solely focus on drinks and opening his drink depot, selling in bulk. 

Little by little, Armel dreams of saving enough to buy his own piece of land and build his family their own home and his children being able to finish school.

loans.use: to purchase additional pharmaceutical items to sell at his shop.

loans.name: Maria Santos

texts.es:
María, lucha todos los días por dar a su familia lo necesario para salir adelante, es acompañada y madre de cuatro hijos de 15, 13, 11 y 8 años de edad, todos comparten una misma vivienda; trabaja en la siembra de granos básicos y crianza de aves de corral,  todos colaboran en este negocio, en un horario de siete de la mañana a tres de la tarde, su negocio funciona desde hace 5 años y nace por la necesidad de tener una mejor calidad de vida, su ventaja es que trabaja en un terreno propio.
Utilizará el préstamo para comprar abono, fertilizantes, insecticidas, herbecidas, concentrados, vitaminas y pollos de engorde, le ayudar a mejorar la productividad de sus cultivos, tendrá mejor rentabilidad de su negocio.
Su sueño es mantenerse trabajando para cancelar la deuda, mejorar el estilo de vida de su familia y brindar a sus hijos oportunidades de superarse académicamente.
texts.en:
Maria works every day to give her family what is necessary to get ahead. She is married and is the mother of four children, ages 15, 13, 11, and 8. They all share the same home. She plants basic grains and raises barnyard fowl. They all contribute to this business, with a schedule from 7 in the morning to 3 in the afternoon. Her business has been functioning for 5 years and was born from the need to have a better quality of life. Her advantage is that she works on her own land.

She will use the loan to buy compost, fertilizers, insecticides, herbicides, concentrated feeds, vitamins, and chickens to fatten. This will help her improve the productivity of her crops, and she will have better profitability from her business.

Her dream is to keep working to pay off the debt, improve the lifestyle of her family, and offer her children opportunities to better themselves academically.

loans.use: to buy compost, fertilizers, insecticides, herbicides, concentrated feeds, vitamins, and chickens to fatten

loans.name: Matondo (2) Group

texts.en:
Marina is a micro-entrepreneur in Brazzaville, the Republic of Congo. For the last seven years, Marina has worked hard to support herself, her husband, and her four nieces and nephews. Starting with a single taxi that she rented out, Marina has now expanded into a small business selling various sodas and home-made local drinks such as ginger juice, bissap juice (made from hibiscus leaves), and yogurt.  

In 2012, Marina discovered HOPE Congo and joined the community bank group Matondo (2). Marina is now on her seventh loan cycle with HOPE Congo and helps lead a sub-group of three other micro-entrepreneurs. She would like to take out a loan of 500,000 XAF (Central African CFA francs) to invest in her drink business and purchase additional juices and sodas to sell. Warm and welcoming with her clients, Marina hopes to one day move on from just selling drinks to traveling to Dubai and bringing back goods such as tiles to sell in Brazzaville. In the future, Marina dreams of being able to save up enough money to buy her own piece of land and build a home.

loans.use: to invest in her drink business and purchase additional juices and sodas to sell.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a 19-year-old businesswoman. She is single and lives in the Nyanga District of Zimbabwe. She has been successfully buying and selling clothes, shoes, and blankets. She has been trained as a Learner Guide with Camfed Zimbabwe. 

With the requested loan, Josephine intends to make bulk purchases of clothes, shoes, and blankets. With additional profits, she hopes to improve her standard of living and create employment in her community.

loans.use: to make bulk purchases of clothes, shoes, and blankets.

loans.name: Scovia

texts.en:
Scovia is 34 years old and lives in the town of Hoima in the Hoima region of Uganda. She is married and has three children who are all currently in school. For the past eight years, Scovia has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells timber. 

To help expand her business, Scovia has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more timber for sale, and will help Scovia to generate greater profits and take care of her family's basic needs. Scovia hopes that in the future, she will be able to own a wholesale shop. 

Scovia is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Scovia who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more timber for sale.

loans.name: Maria Elizabeth

texts.es:
La socia Maria Elizabeth se sigue dedicando al negocio de venta de frutas, la socia lleva a diferentes lugares, la socia vende platanos, naranjas y manzanas , la socia ya tiene varios años en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es tener un local donde pueda vender las frutas . La socia solicita el crédito para comprar naranjas, plátanos y uvas . 

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Maria Elizabeth continues in the business of selling fruit that she takes to different locations. She sells bananas, oranges and apples.  

She's been in this business for several years now, and she's doing very well. Her dream is to have a stall where she can sell the fruit.

She requests the loan to buy oranges, bananas and grapes. 

She is grateful for this loan opportunity and she promises to make her repayments on time.

loans.use: to buy oranges, bananas and grapes.

loans.name: Thendral Shg-Kumbakonam Group

texts.en:
People Action for Transformation (PAT) manages Thendral Self Help Group, which consists of nine members. Kalaiselvi, the leader of this group, is living in Kumbakonam village, Tanjore district.

52-year-old Kalaiselvi lives in her own house with her children. She is a widow who lost her husband a few years back. Life has been pretty hard on her but she is a strong woman. 

Kalaiselvi is requesting a loan to purchase a smokeless stove, as it is easy to use, relatively cheap and reduces the indoor pollution, whereas traditional stoves consume time and money and the smoke emitted from this stove can lead to respiratory diseases.

Along with Kalaiselvi, the other members are requesting loans to purchase smokeless stoves to lead a healthier life.

loans.use: to buy a smokeless stove

loans.name: Paulino

texts.es: Paulino vive en concubinato y tiene 5 hijos Paulino vive en La Paz en una casa de ladrillo y cemento que es de su propiedad Paulino esta jubilado pero tiene una actividad, posee una tienda de barrio en la que vende comestibles y otros productos Paulino necesita un credito para comprar azucar, fideos y arroz por quintales además de cajas de enlatados Paulino es la unica fuente de ingresos en su hogar, por eso necesita su ayuda
texts.en: Paulino lives with his partner and has five children. He lives in La Paz in a brick and mortar house which he owns. Paulino is retired, but he has an economic activity. He owns a neighborhood store where he sells food and other products. Paulino needs a loan in order to buy sugar, noodles and rice in quintals and also cases of canned goods. Paulino is the only source of income in his household; therefore, he needs your help.

loans.use: to buy sugar, noodles, and rice in quintals and also cases of canned goods

loans.name: Bety

texts.es:
La socia Bety  se dedica al negocio de venta de productos de belleza, la socia vende lápiz labiales, cremas y perfumes, la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 7:00 p.m, la socia ya tiene varios años en este negocio, el sueño de la socia es tener un local donde pueda vender los productos de belleza. La socia solicita le crédito para comprar cremas, lápiz labiales y perfumes.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Bety makes a living selling beauty products. She sells lipsticks, creams and perfumes. She works from 8:00am until 7:00pm. 

She has been in this business for several years now. Her dream is to have a stall where she can sell the beauty products.

She requests the loan to buy creams, lipsticks and perfumes.

She is grateful for the loan and she promises to make her payments on time.

loans.use: to buy creams, lipsticks and perfumes.

loans.name: Oppa

texts.en:
Oppa is a 19-year-old businesswoman from the Guruve District of Zimbabwe. For income, she sells new and second-hand jackets, shirts, and dresses at a small stall at the local flea market. In addition to being an inspiration to young women in her community because of her entrepreneurial skills, Oppa is a Camfed Learner Guide who voluntarily instructs students on how to increase their well-being. 

As for the Kiva loan, Oppa will purchase jackets, dresses, shirts, and shoes to increase her stock levels. An increase in income will enable her to support herself and her family members. Oppa also intends to help the underprivileged children in her community.

loans.use: To purchase more jackets, dresses, shirts, and shoes to increase her stock levels.

loans.name: La Reussite 2 (2) Group

texts.en:
Marie is a member of the community bank group LA REUSSITE 2 (2) in Brazzaville, the Republic of Congo. Like the other members of her group, Marie is a micro-entrepreneur and has a small stall selling dried and salted fish in the market. Times were difficult during the past rainy season in Congo – not as many fish were available and those who sell in bulk raised their prices. Marie used her creativity to still keep customers by cutting her fish up into smaller, more manageable portions for people to buy, and charged lower prices than her competitors. 

As a mother of three, Marie is constantly thinking of ways to improve her business so that she can take better care of her family. Since joining HOPE Congo in 2010, Marie is now on her 7th loan cycle with LA REUSSITE 2 (2). She would like to take out a small loan of 300,000 CFA to purchase additional dried fish to sell. Little by little, Marie hopes to increase her savings with higher profits. Eventually, she aspires to buy her own piece of land and build a home for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional dried fish to sell

loans.name: La Reussite 2 (1) Group

texts.en:
Irène is a single mother of five living and working in Brazzaville, the Republic of Congo. In order to support all of her children, four of whom are still in school and four of her sister’s children, Irène sells palm oil at the market. 

Irène has been selling palm oil, a staple in many traditional Congolese dishes, for the past six years and discovered HOPE Congo in 2011. She joined a community bank group with HOPE Congo called La Reussite 2 (1), and leads a sub-group of nine of micro-entrepreneurs in Brazzaville. 

Now on her seventh loan cycle with HOPE Congo, Irène would like to take out a loan of 300,000 XAF to purchase palm oil in bulk to sell. 

She hopes to grow her activities to eventually have her own stand that also sells fou-fou, a traditional Congolese food made from cassava root, and peanuts.

loans.use: to purchase palm oil in bulk to sell at the market

loans.name: Dunduliza Group

texts.en:
Yohana is a father of school-aged children. He is in is forties and married. He is a fruit vendor selling a variety of fruit, including bananas, mangoes, oranges, pawpaws, and avocados. He has been managing this business for ten years. Yohana sells fruit from 7am to 6pm daily and is able to make a small profit each month. 

Yohana is seeking a loan to improve his business and enable him to purchase enough stock to meet demand, especially in this period of fasting for Muslims. Yohana will replenish more fresh fruit to resell. He will share this loan with his loan group, "DUNDULIZA," which consists of five members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to replenish more fresh fruits to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to get help for his coffee crop.

loans.name: Ester
