She will buy 500 blocks, 15 bags of cement, 2 quintals of iron, 7 metres of sand, a truckload of stone and pay for labour. 
 
Teresa has dreams: she wants to continue to remodel for her grandchildren, having a well remodeled house. She also wants to leave the country and go to visit her children in the United States together with her husband, that her children will be good people along with her grandchildren, and to have better crops in her fields.

loans.use: to buy 500 blocks, 15 bags of cement, 2 quintals of iron, 7 metres of sand, a truckload of stone and labour for the construction of a kitchen.

loans.name: Toba's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe est composé de  femmes très actives dans ce banc villageois  et dans leurs activités génératrices de revenu en général. Il créé en Décembre 2010 et regroupe en son sein des femmes  qui sont toutes issues du même quartier et ont une bonne entente et solidarité entre les membres. Elles ont comme activité principale le petit commerce.

Madame Toba  (debout à la deuxième position de la gauche vers droite avec une main levée), est emprunteur vedette du groupe. Elle est  âgée de 57 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 02 enfants uniquement des filles. C’est une dame très déterminée dans son commerce de bouillie de mil qu’elle vend devant la porte de l’hôpital régional. Pour se faire elle achète du mil, fait les lavages nécessaires, le séchage et afin l’achemine au moulin pour transformation avant de passer à la cuisson.  

Avec ce prêt, elle va acheter 05 sacs de mil pour 10 000 Fr CFA l’un, un sac de sucre de 50 Kg pour 25 000 Fr CFA et le reste elle s’approvisionnera en bois de chauffe.
 
Avec les bénéfices, elle compte améliorer les conditions de vie de la famille (nourriture, prise en charge sanitaire et scolaire), d’une part et d’autre augmenter son épargne.
texts.en:
This group is made up of women who are very active their businesses and in the banc villageois. This banc villageois was established in December 2010 and is made up of women who all come from the same area, get along with each other, and share a feeling of solidarity. They all work primarily in small-scale commerce.

Toba (standing second from the left with her hand raised) is the featured borrower of this group. She is 57 years old, married, and is a mother of two girls. 

Toba is very determined in her business and works selling millet porridge in front of the regional hospital. To do this she buys millet, washes it properly, dries it, then grinds it up to prepare it for cooking.

With this loan, she is going to buy five sacs of millet for 10,000 francs CFA each and a 50-kilogram sac of sugar for 25,000 francs CFA. She will use the rest to buy fire wood.

With the earnings she plans to improve her family's living conditions (food, health and school costs) and increase her savings.

loans.use: to buy millet, sugar, and firewood

loans.name: Raquilin

texts.en: Raquilin is 48 years old, and is single. She works in their local government unit. Raquilin needs to work hard because she wanted to help support her nephews and niece in pursuing their studies. While working in the office, Raquilin has a tricycle that is operated by her cousin. She receives 100 PHP daily as payment for the rent of her tricycle. Raquilin wants to repaint her tricycle but she cant do it because she doesn’t have budget for it. In this connection, Raquilin is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP to buy paint and fuel for the maintenance of her tricycle. She hopes to make her tricycle look new and to be able to extend her support for her relatives.

loans.use: to buy paint and fuel for the maintenance of her tricycle.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies.

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
Nena previously accessed an 25,000 PHP loan that she used to buy more quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. Her earnings were a big help in their personal, household and business expenditures. Her business has been running for more than ten years now and it continues to grow. Her loan is one of the main reasons why it keeps on growing. 
 
She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan for her to purchase raw ingredients like rice, pork, chicken and vegetables, and products needed for her business. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her family's daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Nena dreams to have more loyal customers and hopes to have a better future. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week, and she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw ingredients like rice, pork, chicken and vegetables, and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel has been selling candies, jellies, 'samalamig' and other products for many years. She also manages a direct selling business in her village, earning a good income for her family. She used the income from her previous loan to buy direct sale items and products. She successfully repaid her loan. 

Maricel is requesting a loan to purchase more merchandise to sell. She will use her loan to improve her sales and her additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family. Maricel appears here in a photo at her direct selling business.

Maricel hopes for her business to grow and dreams that her family will always be happy and healthy. Each week, she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy additional supplies and merchandise needed for her business

loans.name: Renato

texts.en: Renato is 19 years old, married and had a child. He is a farmer and a vendor too with his wife. They sell eggplants, beans and tomatoes. They manage the business well in order to attain good sales. He wanted to sell more goods so he is now asking for additional capital of 6,000 PHP to buy eggplants, cabbages, tomatoes and bananas to sell. Good profits will be achieved if they continue offering friendly services as well as selling good products to their customers.

loans.use: to buy eggplants, cabbages, tomatoes and bananas to sell

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita works hard to support her family. Teresita is widowed and has a pig fattening business in the Philippines.

Teresita requested a PHP 19,500 loan through NWTF to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

Teresita has been in this business for 15 years now.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

In the future, Teresita would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Mulibathi

texts.en: Mulibathi is 28, male, and married with 1 child and he also has 2 dependents living with him in Kasese Uganda. He operates a retail shop for 12 hours a day, and has been in that business for one year. Mulibathi is a hardworking man with a dream of buying land where he can build a residential house for his family. He will use the loan facility to buy land so as to achieve his dream. Mulibathi is faced with the challenge of price fluctuations of retail products.

loans.use: to buy land.

loans.name: Aminata's Group

texts.fr: Ce groupe est constitué de 06 femmes qui habitent le même quartier; elles ont comme principale activité l'élevage . Aminata l'emprunteur en vedette est la responsable du groupe, elle est âgée de 45 ans, mariée et mère de six enfants dont 2 filles. Elle est debout à gauche sur la photo. Elle mène une activité d'élevage de moutons .Elle capitalise une bonne expérience de plus de 03 ans. Avec son prêt elle compte acheter 05 moutons et des chèvres pour une opération Tabaski. L’activité marche bien car il y a d'autres qui font la même activité et elle a beaucoup de bénéfices. Avec ses bénéfices elle va subvenir à ses besoins personnels.
texts.en:
This group is composed of six women, all neighbors. Their main business is animal husbandry.

Aminata, the star borrower for this loan, is the group’s leader. She is 45 years old, married, and a mother of six, including two daughters. She is standing to the left in the picture. Her business is sheep rearing. She is building on a good experience of over three years.

With her loan, she plans to purchase five sheep and goats for the feast of Tabaski (a.k.a. Eid al-Adha). Her business is thriving, as attested by the fact that others are also in it and that she makes a good income. With the profit, she will provide for her personal needs.

loans.use: to buy sheep and goats.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy new decoration materials to improve her business.

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Jean works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling gasoline. Jean is borrowing 14,000 PHP (Philippine Pesos) through NWTF (Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc.) to purchase additional stocks like coffee, soft drinks, sardines, etc. to sell at her general store business.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and now she has requested an additional loan to further build her business.

Jean has been sustaining her business activities through her past four loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks like coffee, soft drinks, sardines, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Loc

texts.en:
Loc is a 53-year-old married man living in Ho Chi Minh City. He has three children. He and his wife earn a living running a soft drinks shop, which they have done for 15 years. 

Loc would like to take loan to buy a greater variety of beverages to stock in his shop. He hopes this will enable him to better meet the needs of his customers and increase the turnover of his business. He also hopes that through the loan, his business will generate a higher income and will help him to improve his family's living conditions and enable him to set aside some savings.

loans.use: to buy a greater variety of beverages to stock in his shop.

loans.name: Oumy's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe de 30 femmes fait parti du banc villageois qui a été crée le 24 octobre 2012. Il en est son 4eme cycle : il regroupe des femmes qui vivent dans le même village et ceux des environs. Une bonne entente règne entres elles et font comme activité le commerce et l’embouche.
Aissatou la vedette du groupe est en position debout sur la photo et a levé la main pour se distinguer. Elle est âgée de 29 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants dont 3 garçons.
Elle envisage de continuer son activité de restauration, vente de repas dans les marchés hebdomadaires de la zone.
Avec le prêt elle va acheter 2 sacs de riz à 12500f, 5 kg d’oignons à 350f le kg, 5 litres d’huile à 4500f, du vinaigre, du poivre, du bouillon, du piment. Elle achète aussi divers autres produits alimentaires pour les besoins de la restauration. Elle vend le plat à 500f.
Les bénéfices sont utilise pour s’occuper de sa famille et épargner
texts.en:
This group of thirty women belongs to the village finance group created on October 24th, 2012. This is their fourth loan cycle. The group is composed of women living in one village and its area. The women get along very well. Their businesses are retail and animal husbandry.

Aissatou, the group’s star borrower, is standing in the picture and raised her hand to stand out. She is 29 years old. She is married and a mother of four, including three boys. She plans to continue her food business, selling meals at weekly markets in the area.

With the loan, she will purchase two bags of rice costing 12,500 XOF, five kilos of onions at 350 XOF per kilo, five liters of oil at 4,500 XOF each, vinegar, black pepper, stock, and hot pepper. She also purchases various other food products depending on her business needs. She sells each meal for 500 XOF.

She uses her profits to take care of her family and increase her savings.

loans.use: to purchase various food products.

loans.name: Lanie

texts.en:
Lanie is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fishing business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 15,000 PHP (Philippine Pesos) through NWTF (Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc.) to purchase additional fishing nets and other materials for her fishing business. Lanie has been in this business for ten years. She earns more income from raising pigs.

Lanie has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional fishing nets and other materials for her fishing business.

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en:
This is Mwanamisi. She previously accessed a loan that she used to stock her retail shop business. Her earnings were a big help for her personal, household, and business expenditures.

She is requesting a loan to purchase wheat flour, maize flour, cooking oil, rice, and beans for resale. She appreciates Kiva for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, maize flour, cooking oil, rice, and beans for resale.

loans.name: Con

texts.en:
Con is a 32-year-old married woman. She lives with her one child and husband in Ho Chi Minh City. For two years, she has operated a cafe in front of her house. 

Con would like a loan to purchase a greater range and quantity of beverages and coffee to stock her store. She hopes this will enable her to better meet the needs of her customers and attract additional customers. 

Con also hopes that through her loan, she will be able to increase her income and save money for any future difficulties facing her family.

loans.use: to purchase a greater range and quantity of beverages and coffee to stock her store.

loans.name: Awa's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe de 28 femmes fait parti du banc villageois qui a été crée le 24 octobre 2012. Il en est son 4eme cycle : il regroupe des femmes qui vivent dans le même village et ceux des environs. Une bonne entente règne entres elles et font comme activité le commerce et l’embouche.
Adama la vedette du groupe est en position debout sur la photo et a levé la main pour se distinguer. Elle est âgée de 27 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants dont 2 garçons.
Elle envisage de faire du commerce d’huile d’arachide et du mil. Elle va acheter 3 sacs d’arachide à 27500f le sac, elle le transforme en huile et peut avoir 35 litre d’huile pour vendre le litre à 1000f. Concernant le mil elle achète 5 sacs à 7500f le sac, elle le fait stocker jusqu'à l’approche de l’hivernage pour le vendre à 225 le kg.
Les bénéfices sont utilisés pour les besoins familiaux et personnels.
texts.en:
This group of 28 women belongs to the village finance group created on October 24th, 2012. This is their fourth loan cycle. The group is composed of women living in one village and its area. The women get along very well. Their businesses are retail and animal husbandry.

Adama, the group’s star borrower, is standing in the picture and raised her hand to stand out. She is 27 years old. She is married and a mother of five, including two boys. She plans to retail ground nut oil and millet. For millet specifically, she will purchase five bags costing 7,500 XOF each, and will have it stored until the rainy season draws near, at which point she will resell it at 225 XOF per kilo.

She uses her profits to take care of her family and herself.

loans.use: to buy millet and ground nuts.

loans.name: Ndeye's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe de 33 femmes fait parti du banc villageois qui a été crée le 24, octobre 2012. Ce banc regroupe des femmes qui habitent dans le même village et ceux des alentours. Une bonne entente les anime. La plupart font du commerce. Nogoye debout à droite de la photo et levant la main, est âgée de 38 ans. Elle est mariée et mère d'une fille. Elle envisage de faire de la couture. Elle achète 7 draps à raison de 3000f l'un, elle va les coudre elle même; pour cela elle va acheter 3 paquets de fil 2500f un paquet. Elle vend le drap fini à 9000f ou 13000f à crédit.
Avec les bénéfices, elle prend en charge ses besoins et renforce son activité. Elle s'occupe de sa fille qui va à l'école.
texts.en:
This group of 33 women belongs to the village finance group created on October 24th, 2012. The group is composed of women living in one village and its area. The women get along very well. Most of them are in retail.

Nogoye, the group’s star borrower, is standing to the right in the picture and raising her hand. She is 38 years old. She is married and mother to one daughter. She plans to do sewing. She will purchase seven sheets of fabrics costing 3,000 XOF each, and sew them herself, for which she will purchase three spools of thread at 2,500 apiece. She retails finished sheets for 9,000 XOF cash or 13,000 with financing.

She uses her profits to take care of her needs and grow her business. She provides for her daughter, who goes to school.

loans.use: to buy sheets of fabrics.

loans.name: Nho

texts.en:
Nho is 32 years old and married with one son. She lives with her family in a small house in Ho Chi Minh City. She and her husband earn income through running a food stall that sells seafood for people in their community. 

She started her business five months ago. She intends to take a loan to gradually expand her business by buying good quality seafood and soft drinks to sell to her customers. 

She hopes her business runs smoothly and will help her to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to buy good quality seafood and soft drinks to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Yen

texts.en:
Yen, 61, is married and has one son. She lives with her family in Ho Chi Minh City. Her husband supports his family by selling building materials. Yen earns an income selling fruits in front of their house. 

She started this business 20 years ago. She is requesting a loan to expand her business by buying a greater variety of fruits to better satisfy her customers.

She hopes her business runs smoothly and will generate a higher income to assist her in improving her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To buy a greater quantity and variety of fruits to sell

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is 61 years old and married with seven children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 10,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock like soft drinks, milk, spices, eggs, noodles, etc., to sell.

Lydia has borrowed and paid 20 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 10 years and also earns an income from buying and selling charcoal.

Lydia aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock like soft drinks, milk, spices, eggs, noodles, etc., to sell

loans.name: My

texts.en:
My is 28 years old and married with one child. She lives with her family in a small house in Ho Chi Minh City. She and her husband earn income through selling slippers and hair accessories. 

She started her business four years ago. She intends to take a loan to gradually expand her business by buying a greater quantity and variety of slippers and hairpins to sell to her customers. 

She hopes her business runs smoothly and will help her to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To buy slippers and hairpins to sell from her store

loans.name: Hala

texts.en:
Hala is a 25-year-old married woman living with her husband and three children. Her husband is the main income provider for the family. Hala has been working in the agricultural sector for the past five years in order to be able to support her family financially. 

Today, she is asking to borrow a loan from Kiva partner Vitas. s.a.l. to purchase merchandise for her business, such as seeds and seedlings for planting. She is certain that with the new merchandise, she will be able to increase her income.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise for her business, such as seeds and seedlings for planting.

loans.name: Ruel

texts.en:
Ruel owns, maintains, and operates an auto repair shop. He has been successful in this business for five years, and he repaid his previous loan used for the business. He also finds ways to improve his income through his side job.

In relation to this, he would like to take a new loan to improve his service and to purchase additional supplies like wiring, putty paint, tint, and other materials needed in his repair shop. He is requesting an amount of 20,000 PHP (Philippine Pesos) to maintain his business operations and to buy more stocks of other products needed in his business.

In the future, Ruel hopes to become successful and further enhance his skills necessary to improve his business. He dreams that his family will be always and forever happy and on good terms. 

He meets up with his co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of his life and business, and finds strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT (Center for Community Transformation Credit Cooperative) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for supplies like wiring, putty paint, tint, and other materials needed in his auto repair shop.

loans.name: Merly

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Merly works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from selling vegetables. Merly is borrowing 10,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to buy additional materials and gear for her fishing business.

Merly has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to repair and renovate her home.

loans.use: to buy additional materials and gear for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a dairy cow and poultry.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 25-year-old female, married, with 2 children both attending school, living in Kasese, Uganda.  

She is a food vendor who has been dealing in fresh foods for 5 years and works 7 days a week. She began the business to supplement her husband's little income that he was making for the family. 

Mary will use the loan to buy cabbages, tomatoes, and palm oil. Mary is a hardworking woman who dreams of buying land for her children; however, she is faced with the challenge of the perishability of her products.

loans.use: to buy cabbages, tomatoes, and palm oil  to sell.

loans.name: Mariati

texts.en:
Mariati is a married woman without children, living in Kasese, Uganda. Dealing in produce like beans, maize, and groundnuts, she works for 11 hours, seven days a week. She sells pancakes as additional income. She started her produce business as her main source of income. 

Mariati needs a loan to buy beans, maize, and groundnuts for selling. She is hard-working and looking forward to expanding her business, despite her complaint of seasonal changes.

The extra person in the photo is a fellow trader in the market since the photo was taken when she was at work.

loans.use: to buy beans, maize, and groundnuts for selling.

loans.name: Nhi

texts.en:
Nhi is a 57-year-old single woman. She lives with her family in Ho Chi Minh City. For six years, she has run a business of making metal bolts and metal parts.  

Nhi would like a loan to open a general store from her house that she would operate along side her metal shop. She would like to use the loan to buy a variety of basic products, such as food and beverages, to stock in her general store. She hopes this will enable her to earn additional income and supplement the income that she earns from her metal shop. 

She also hopes that through her loan she will be able to save money for any future difficulties facing her family.

loans.use: to buy a variety of basic products, such as food and beverages, to stock in her new general store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cables, power outlets, lightbulbs, screws, insulation materials, PVC, etc.

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
Marcelina previously accessed a 40,000 PHP loan that she utilized to buy gardening materials such as wire and baskets, and supplies such as seeds and fertilizer. Her earnings were a big help in their personal, household and business expenditures. Aside from her ornamental plants, she also has a direct selling business and she also sells rice for additional income.

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy gardening materials such as wire and baskets, and supplies such as seeds and fertilizer. Her profits from her business will definitely help her sustain her family's daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Marcelina dreams that all her businesses will continue to flourish and hopes to give her family a good future. She meets up with her fellowship co-members to share stories of her work every week and also to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies there.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for gardening materials such as wire and baskets, and supplies such as seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Necitas

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Necitas works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and she also earns additional income from raising pigs. Necitas is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to purchase additional materials such as fishing nets, etc. for her fishing business.

Necitas has been sustaining her business activities through her past 3 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials like fishing nets, etc. for her fishing business

loans.name: Minda

texts.en:
Minda is 48 years old and married with eight children. She earns a living by farming sugarcane in the Philippines. 

Minda is borrowing 17,000 PHP (Philippine Pesos) through NWTF (Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc.) to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies. She has been farming sugarcane for ten years and also earns additional income from a general store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream--to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy farm implements and poultry.

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Jhona is 20 years old and is one of two children in the family. Her mother Analyn is a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon and supports the family through her general store business in the Philippines.

Jhona is studying for a Bachelor of Science in Civil Engineering and is currently on her 5th of this 5 year course.

Analyn is borrowing 16,000 to pay for tuition fees for the 2nd semester of the school year 2013-14.

When she graduates, Jhona plans to be gainfully employed so she could help improve the quality of life of her family.

loans.use: to pay for tuition fees.

loans.name: Binti

texts.en:
Binti is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work. She operates a kiosk shop and a business selling clothes.

She is asking for a loan to buy more stocks of wheat flour, cooking oil, and maize flour for her business. She is grateful for the financial support she has received.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of wheat flour, cooking oil, and maize flour for her business.

loans.name: Marwa

texts.en:
Marwa is a 20-year-old Lebanese single woman. She has worked as a private teacher since 2011. She chooses this profession because she feels that she is helping students to get the education they need. She has arranged a special room in her house where she receives her students and has equipped it with required materials and supplies. 

Today, she is applying to borrow a loan from Kiva partner Vitas. s.a.l. to buy a new laptop to help her in her work and to improve her teaching skills. She is very optimistic about her future and wishes to receive more students in the upcoming school season.

loans.use: to buy a new laptop.

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa is 31 years old and married with four children, all of whom are in school.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy more items to sell like soap, noodles, eggs, sugar, etc.

Marissa has borrowed and paid 5 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 4 years and also earns an income from buying and selling charcoal.

Marissa aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell like soap, noodles, eggs, sugar, etc

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fishing business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 15,000 PHP (Philippine Pesos) through NWTF (Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc.) to buy additional fishing net for her fishing business. She has been in this business for 16 years. Virginia earns more income from buying and selling mangoes.

Virginia has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of repairing and renovating her home in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional fishing net for her fishing business.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia appreciates her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards. She is requesting a loan to purchase more maize for resale. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. 

She thanks Yehu Microfinance Trust for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase more maize for resale.

loans.name: Maria Mercedes

texts.es:
María, necesita invertir nuevamente en su negocio de venta de frutas y verduras, se decidió por un nuevo crédito para comprar tomates, pepinos, zanahorias, piñas, papayas, ejotes, repollos, chiles, manzanas, uvas, etc., brindara una mejor atención y productos frescos a sus clientes.  
El préstamo anterior fue de mucha ayuda para mantenerse trabajando y creciendo en su negocio, su familia sigue unida, ha cancelado sus deudas y mejorado sus ganacias.
texts.en: Maria needs to invest in her business, selling fruits and vegetables, again. She decided to ask for a new loan to buy tomatoes, cucumbers, carrots, pineapples, papayas, green beans, cabbages, chilli peppers, apples, grapes, etc. This will allow her to provide a better service, and fresh products to her customers. The previous loan was a great help to her to continue working and growing in her business. Her family is still together, they have paid off their debts and they have improved their profits.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes, cucumbers, carrots, pineapples, papayas, green beans, cabbages, chilli peppers, apples, grapes, etc.

loans.name: Lan's Group

texts.en:
Lan is 43 years old and lives with her one child and husband. Her husband works as a porter in the local market. For the past three years, Lan has been running a food stall from the front of her house to earn an income to support her family. 

Lan is the Group Leader of a seven-member loan group that lives in Ho Chi Minh City. In the picture, she stands in the center. Each of the other group members are requesting loans to fund income-generating activities.

Lan is requesting a loan to purchase a better quality and greater variety of food and beverages to sell from her stall. She hopes this will enable her to better meet the needs of her customers and attract additional ones. She also hopes that through her loan, she will be able to increase her income and save money for any future difficulties facing her family.

loans.use: to purchase a better quality and greater variety of food and beverages to sell from her stall.

loans.name: Nabiha

texts.en: Nabiha is a 31-year-old, married mother of two children. In 2012 she decided to start working from her house by selling homemade foods to help her family and to improve their lifestyle. Today, Nabiha is demanding a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l. to better her business merchandise and give the best product to her clients. She has a very good reputation in her hometown by giving the best products. She is very certain that she will sell all of her products. She hopes that in the future, she might open her own store, and she insists that she will be a permanent customer to be able to develop always her business.

loans.use: to better her business merchandise for her foods business.

loans.name: Nawal

texts.en:
Nawal is a 59-year-old married woman from Jenin city. She lives with her husband and four sons in a small house. Her husband is a worker in a local factory where he gets a low income. This income barely covers the family's needs.

Nawal works as a teacher in a public school. She loves her job and she always looks for new ways of teaching and using educational tools. She took a USD loan from FATEN. This loan will help her to buy a new laptop for her work. By taking this loan, Nawal will be able to search and read more through the internet.

She appears in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a new laptop for her work

loans.name: Josefa

texts.en:
Josefa previously accessed a 25,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures. Her business has existed for more than 10 years now and it continues to grow with the help of the loan lent to her.

She would like to apply for a new 20,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Josefa hopes to be more successful in business and dreams to have a better life. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week, which is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Maa Tarini (A) Group

texts.en:
The women of the Maa Tarini SHG are from a small village in the Cuttack district in Odisha in the eastern part of the India. The group is composed of 11 women who earn their living by raising animals like cattle and chickens, selling milk, and cultivating and selling vegetables. They need additional capital to maintain, enhance or expand their businesses and decided to apply for a loan with People's Forum. They are excited and full of hope to begin this new season with solid goals and dreams. 

Rasmita is a 38-year-old mother of one child. In the picture, the lady standing in front is Rasmita. She completed three years of formal education but due to the poor economic condition of her family, had to leave her education behind. Along with all the clients of People's Forum, Rasmita realizes that education is a vital key to a successful future for her child. She says that her business is running quite well and, because of its success, she will be able to register her child in a good school this year. Rasmita is engaged in vegetable cultivation and she produces potatoes, tomatoes, onions, and seasonal vegetables. She is applying for her first loan with People's Forum. The requested funds will be used to purchase standard quality seeds, fertilizers and pesticides for her vegetable cultivation. With an optimistic spirit and positive attitude, Rasmita looks forward to this new season with its challenges, blessings and successes. On behalf of her colleagues, Rasmita expresses gratitude and appreciation for the support from Kiva investors throughout the world who lend such necessary and vital support.

loans.use: To purchase standard quality seeds, fertilizers and pesticides for her vegetable cultivation.

loans.name: Aireen

texts.en:
As a single parent of two children, Aireen works hard to support her family.

She has a buy-and-sell banana business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from farming rootcrops. Aireen is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy additional bananas to sell for her business.

Aireen has been sustaining her business activities through her past four loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional bananas to sell for her business

loans.name: Carina

texts.en:
Carina is 51 years old and widowed with one child. She works very hard to provide for them.

Carina runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional items like eggs, snack foods, cooking oil, sugar, salt, coffee, etc. to sell.

Carina has been in this business for 33 years and sells a variety of items such as eggs, snack foods, cooking oil, sugar, salt, coffee, etc. 

In the future, Carina would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional items like eggs, snack foods, cooking oil, sugar, salt, and coffee to sell

loans.name: Micaela Bastidas Group

texts.es:
La socia Martina pertenece al banco comunal MICAELA BASTIDAS, él banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.
La socia Martina continua con su negocio de tienda de abarrotes, la socia es una persona responsable, la socia vende diferentes tipos de productos para todos sus clientes que le solicitan, la socia a la vez sigue dedicándose a la venta de caldos, la socia desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para la compra de arroz, azucar, leche entre otros.
La socia se siente agradecida por el crédito otorgado y se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas.
Los demás socios se dedican la venta de ropa, productos de belleza, venta de ropa(lencería).

La socia que sale en la foto adjunta pidio permiso para llegar tarde a la reunion por motivos de trabajo.
texts.en:
Martina is a member of the communal bank MICAELA BASTIDAS. The bank is located in the District of Cusco in Cusco Province, Department of Cusco.
Martina continues to work on her business, a groceries store. She is a responsible person, and she sells different types of products for all her customers who ask her for them. She also makes a living selling broths, and she would like to continue working like this in order to keep supporting her family.
She is asking for a loan to buy rice, sugar and milk, among other things.
She is grateful for the loan she was granted, and promises to pay it back according to her repayment plan.
The other members make a living selling clothes, beauty products and underwear.

The member who appears in the attached photo asked for permission to arrive late to the meeting because of work reasons.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar and milk, among other things.

loans.name: Vivigyn

texts.en:
Vivigyn cultivates flowers on a farm to sell in order to earn a living. She has been in this business for many years and she earns well. 

She had successfully repaid her previous loan used for farming. Recently, she took a new loan to purchase fertilizer and seedlings.

In the future, Vivigyn hopes to purchase equipment to use in her flower production.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and seedling

loans.name: Maria Cristina

texts.en:
Maria Cristina is 23 years old and married with two children. She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines. 

Maria Cristina is borrowing 10,000 PHP (Philippine Pesos) through NWTF (Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc.) to purchase fertilizers and other farm equipment.

She has been farming rice for six years and also earns additional income from raising pigs. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream--to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to puchase fertilizers and other farm equipment.

loans.name: Celia

texts.en:
Celia is a married woman with two children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Celia is 44 years old and has one child who is still in school.

Celia has a general store business in the Philippines. She requested a 10,000 PHP (Philippine Pesos) loan amount through NWTF (Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc.) to buy more groceries to sell in her general store.

Celia has been in this business for ten years. She would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Chari

texts.en:
Chari appreciates her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards and enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income.

She is requesting a loan to purchase more charcoal for resale . She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal for resale

loans.name: Mjeni

texts.en:
This is Mjeni. She greatly appreciates Kiva lenders for their financial support.

She is requesting a loan to purchase more goats for her business. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

loans.use: to purchase more goats for her business.

loans.name: Bach

texts.en:
Bach is a 40-year-old married woman. She lives with her two children and her husband in Ho Chi Minh City. For 20 years, she and her husband have run a business making and selling bags.

Bach would like a loan to purchase a better quality material to make bags for her customers. She hopes this will enable her to better meet the needs of her customers and attract additional customers. 

She also hopes that through her loan, she will be able to increase her income and save money for any future difficulties facing her family.

loans.use: to purchase better quality materials to make bags for her customers

loans.name: Xinh's Group

texts.en:
Xinh is a 21-year-old single woman and lives with her family in Ho Chi Minh City. For the past 5 years Xinh has been running a general store from the front of her house to earn an income to support her family. Xinh is the Group Leader of a 4-member loan group that live in Ho Chi Minh City. In the picture she is wearing a black shirt standing on the right. Each of the other group members are requesting loans to fund income-generating activities.

Xinh is requesting a loan to purchase a better quality and greater variety of products, such as food and beverages, to restock her store. She hopes this will enable her to better meet the needs of her customers and attract additional ones. She also hopes that through her loan she will be able to increase her income and save money for any future difficulties facing her family.

loans.use: to purchase a better quality and greater variety of products, such as food and beverages, to restock her store

loans.name: Be

texts.en:
Be is a 44-year-old married woman with a son. She lives with her husband and son in Ho Chi Minh City. 

Be has been running a food stall for nearly two years. She sells Hue noodles for people in the local community. She intends to take a loan to buy a greater quantity and variety of food to meet her customers' demands. 

She hopes that through the loan, she can earn more money with her current business and save additional amounts for reinvestment.

loans.use: to buy a greater quantity and variety of food to meet her customers' demands.

loans.name: Cam

texts.en:
Cam is a 27-year-old married woman. She lives with her two children and husband in Ho Chi Minh City. For two years, she has operated a coffee shop in front of her house that sells soft drinks, coffee, and breakfast to people in her community.

Cam would like a loan to purchase a greater range and quantity of beverages and coffee to stock in her store. She hopes this will enable her to better meet the needs of her customers and attract additional customers. 

Cam also hopes that through her loan, she will be able to increase her income and save money for any future difficulties facing her family.

loans.use: to purchase a greater range and quantity of beverages and coffee to stock in her store.

loans.name: Khuong

texts.en:
Khuong, 64, is married and lives in Ho Chi Minh City with his family. He has five sons and two daughters. 

Khuong started his business to cover his expenses and to generate income to raise his children. He provides basic motorbike repair services, washes them, and changes oil. He is requesting a loan to expand his business by buying more oil products to sell to his customers. 

He hopes that this will enable him to attract more customers and that he will be able to increase the turnover of his business. He hopes that through the loan he will be able to expand his business activities, and have money to reinvest to his business in the future.

loans.use: To buy more oil products

loans.name: Florife

texts.en:
Florife owns and operates a variety store business to earn a living. She has been successful in this business for eight years, and she repaid her previous loan used for the business. She also finds ways to improve her income by making peanut butter and purchasing beauty products to sell to her regular customers.

Relative to this, Florife would like to take a new loan to increase her product inventory. She is requesting an amount of PHP 40,000 to buy more quantities and varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

In the future, she wants to put up another storehouse and she dreams of becoming a successful businesswoman. Florife meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, allowing her to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, to build social capital, and to repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda is 56 years old and married with three children. She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines. 

Imelda is borrowing 10,000 PHP (Philippine Pesos) through NWTF (Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc.) to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

She has been farming rice for ten years and also earns additional income from a general store. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream--to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha is 44 years old and married with three children.

She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines. Editha is borrowing PHP 19,000 through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Editha has been farming rice  for 10 years and also earns additional income from pig fattening. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is 45 years old and married with four children. She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines. 

Marilyn is borrowing 25,000 PHP (Philippine Pesos) through NWTF (Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc.) to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Marilyn has been farming rice for 14 years and also earns additional income from motorcycle transport. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream--to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Anabel Linda

texts.en:
Anabel Linda is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fishing business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy more material and gear for her fishing business. She has been in this business for five years. She earns more income from raising pigs.

Anabel Linda has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more material and gear for her business

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie is 44 years old and married with two children who are in school. Elvie works very hard to provide for them.

She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like biscuits, canned goods, soft drinks, milk, noodles, etc.

Elvie has been in this business for one year. 

In the future, Elvie would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like biscuits, canned goods, soft drinks, milk, and noodles

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex is a father of four children living in Masindi, Uganda. He used his previous loan to buy produce, such as maize, to sell in season where he managed to get profits. He also has a maize mill for food production and grinding. 

He is a carpenter and has used his proceeds to buy a motorcycle to boost his income and ease movement from one place to another to work. He wants to buy land for farming with this loan and he dreams of educating his children. However, he is affected by seasonal changes and customers who don't pay him on time.

loans.use: to buy land for farming.

loans.name: Oscar Benjamin

texts.es:
Oscar, ha tenido cambios positivos en su economía por la buena inversión del préstamo anterior, compro cerdos, con los que su negocio genero mejores ganancias, ha logrado establecer una granja de pollos de engorde y cubre las necesidades de su familia.
Opta por más capital para comprar concentrado (para cerdos y pollos) y pagara los costos de la recolección de la cosecha de granos básicos, continuara progresando y satisfaciendo a sus  clientes.
texts.en:
There were positive changes in Oscar's financial situation as a result of his previous loan. He bought pigs and made a good profit from them. He also bought poultry to raise so that he could pay for family necessities.

Now he would like another loan to buy special pig and chicken feed, pay for help with his grain harvest, continue making progress, and satisfying his customers.

loans.use: buy special pig and chicken feed, and pay for help with his grain harvest

loans.name: Hong

texts.en:
Hong, a 34-year-old married woman, lives in Ho Chi Minh City with her 3 children. She and her husband run a business that sells a variety of basic goods to people in the local community.

Hong requests a loan to purchase more products, such as soft drinks and snack foods, to stock her store. That will enable her to offer a better range of products to her customers. She hopes her business will run smoothly and she can earn additional income to reinvest in her shop and save for emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase more products, such as soft drinks and snack foods, to stock her store

loans.name: Nia Moja Group

texts.en:
Pendo is in her thirties and has got a girl who is in school. She is not married and manages several services. She runs a pharmacy and provides special exercise to the patients recommended from the hospital (physiotherapy). She also manages a shop selling soft drinks, M-Pesa (a mobile-phone-based money-transfer service), and airtime. She is a doctor by profession, and previously, a civil servant. 

Pendo quit from being employed because she was paid an unsatisfactory salary. She decided to start her own businesses. Pendo has a few helpers and starts business from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. daily and is able to make a good profit each month.

She is now coming to Tujijenge Tanzania to request a loan to be apportioned among Nia Moja, a ten-member group. The group members will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan. 

She will invest her portion to buy a weighing machine and rice and beans for her shop. She dreams of opening a center for her all businesses, and has currently started building.

loans.use: to buy a weighing machine and rice and beans for her shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase agricultural supplies

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
Geraldine has faithfully paid back her previous loan which she used for her business. She has been operating her own rug-making business for years and she earns well from this. Having a bigger responsibility requires more effort to provide for the family's needs, especially for her children. She has to work hard, with the determination of having better income, to provide her child with better education. 

To improve her profit, Geraldine would like to apply for a new loan. With PHP 8,000, she could already purchase more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread, and other materials for her business. She sincerely lets you know her heartfelt thanks and appreciation for this assistance in advance.

In the future, Geraldine hopes that her business will stand and last longer. She dreams to be able to provide her family's needs and to be able to send all her children to school. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and to also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God they study.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for fabric, cloth, thread, needles, and other materials needed in her rug-making business.

loans.name: Night

texts.en:
Night is a 31-year-old female, married with two children, both attending school, and living in Kasese-Uganda. 

She used the previous loan to buy beans to sell. She is still in her businesses of produce and retail. Being a hardworking woman, Night dreams of buying land for her two children and also owning a big produce store although her area is affected by floods. 

Night is requesting a loan to buy sodas, water, beer, and other things to sell

loans.use: to buy sodas, water, beers and other things to sell

loans.name: Albertina

texts.en:
Albertina is taking a loan of $600.00 to improve her business. She is married and is running a kiosk that helps her to generate income for her family. 

She will use the loan to buy stocks to keep in her store, such as milk, sugar, coffee, cigarettes, soap, shampoo, and noodles. She opened her kiosk a year ago with her own working capital of $300.00. 

She is a hard-working woman and she hopes to run a bigger business in the future.

loans.use: to buy milk, sugar, coffee, cigarettes, soap, shampoo, and noodles.

loans.name: Alhaji Ado

texts.en:
Alhaji Ado is a 30-year-old farmer from Gwanki. As a Babban Gona member, Alhaji Ado is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Alhaji Ado can earn up to $2000 per hectare this season from growing maize--more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s average annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags per hectare, which is double the national average of 14. 

However, Alhaji Ado is ambitious and is hoping that as a result of this loan, he will be able to acces quality inputs such as fertilizer and improved seeds that will result in a yield of at least 300 bags of maize per hectare this season. Alhaji Ado is hopeful about what the future holds; he hopes that with the increased income as the result of a high yield, he will finally be able to afford to educate his children, Ismail, Yusufa, and Naziru. 

Alhaji Ado’s dreams do not end here: “Ultimately, I want to make more money for myself and my family,” he said.

loans.use: to access high-quality inputs, such as fertilizer and seeds, in order to double his income and yield.

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en:
Juanita has faithfully paid back her previous loan which she used for her business. She has been operating her own business for more than fifteen years and she earns a good amount from this. Having a bigger family requires more effort to provide for their needs, especially for her four children. She had to work hard, with the determination of having a better income, to provide her children with better education. 

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP (Philippine Pesos) to buy more eggs and grocery items needed in her business. More items to sell will result in better profits. Her profits from business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Juanita hopes that her business will continue to flourish and dreams that her family is always in good health. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies. 

* All CCT (Center for Community Transformation Credit Cooperative) community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for more eggs and grocery items needed in her business.

loans.name: Ma. Editha

texts.en:
Ma. Editha is 50 years old and married with five children. With three children currently in school, Ma. Editha works very hard to provide for them. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items like canned goods, cereals, chocolate drinks, soft drinks, beers, candies, etc. to sell. Ma. Editha has been in this business for 10 years and sells a variety of items. 

In the future, Ma. Editha would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell like canned goods, cereals, chocolate drinks, soft drinks, beers, candies, etc.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana is 60 years old and widowed with four children. She works very hard to provide for them.

She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 10,000 PHP (Philippine Pesos) loan through NWTF (Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc.) to buy items to sell, like shampoo, groceries, etc. Susana has been in this business for one year.

In the future, Susana would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell, like shampoo, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Peterson

texts.en:
Peterson is a 42-year-old humble and hardworking man who hails from the Kisii area in Kenya, an area commonly referred to as a banana-growing region. Through his hard work he has been able to take care of his family of nine children and one wife. Life has not been that good, but he has always managed to put food on the table for his family. 

Peterson's primary sources of income are tea, other crops and small businesses.Being still young all his nine children are still in school and that is why he has to work extra hard so that he can  pay  tuition fees for his children. Peterson believes that education is the key to success and that is why he wants to give all his children that education. For this reason he is seeking a loan of KES 31,200 to be able to purchase a dairy cow that will be of great help to him in terms of generating more income.

Through the loan he will be able to sell milk to his neighbors and the village around, where demand for milk is so high. This loan will be of much help and will help him educate his nine children and be able to give them a brighter future through education.

Peterson’s projections are that after a short period he will be able to increase the number of dairy cows that he has and be able to comfortably repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Sweetsell is 17 years old and is one of three children in the family. Her mother Rebecca is a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon and supports the family through her food vending and a restaurant business in the Philippines. Sweetsell is studying to become a computer programmer and is currently in her 1st year of this 2-year course.

Rebecca is borrowing PHP 9,106  for her daughter, Sweetsell, to pay for tuition fees for the 2nd semester of the school year 2013-14.

When she graduates, Sweetsell plans to be gainfully employed so she could help improve the quality of life of her family.

loans.use: to pay for tuition fees for her daughter.

loans.name: Monaliza

texts.en:
Monaliza is 34 years old and married with four children, who are in school. She works hard to provide for her family. 

She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 22000 PHP (Philippine Pesos) loan through NWTF (Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc.) to purchase stocks to sell, like canned goods, eggs, milk, noodles, spices, etc.

Monaliza has borrowed and paid back 16 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 12 years and also earns an income from buying and selling rice.

She aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college .

loans.use: to purchase stocks to sell, like canned goods, eggs, milk, noodles, spices, etc.

loans.name: Rachael

texts.en:
Rachael is a married woman with four children, all of whom still attend school and are still under her care. They live at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for the children.

Rachael has operated a business selling clothes, which she sells at the market to her town dwellers and her neighbours. She cites her major challenge as being seasonality. Rachael dreams of establishing a boutique in the future.

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase two bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance Trust to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase two bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Nam

texts.en:
Nam is a 49-year-old married woman. She has two children. Her husband is working as a construction worker. Nam lives with her family in Ho Chi Minh City. For 10 years she has operated a food stall to sell meals to people in their community.

Nam would like a loan to purchase new furniture, good quality food, and rice in bulk. She hopes this will enable her to better meet the needs of her customers and attract additional customers. 

She also hopes that through her loan she will be able to increase her income and save money for any future difficulties facing her family.

loans.use: to purchase new furniture, good quality food, and rice in bulk

loans.name: Dung

texts.en:
Dung is a 38-year-old married woman. She lives with two children and her husband in Ho Chi Minh City. Her husband earns money as a driver for hire. For 15 years, she has run a business of sewing and selling  clothes.

Dung would like a loan to purchase one more sewing machine for her shop. She hopes this will enable her to better meet the needs of her customers and attract additional customers. 

She also hopes that through her loan she will be able to increase her income and save money for any future difficulties facing her family.

loans.use: to purchase one more sewing machine for her shop

loans.name: Oscar Omar

texts.es:
Oscar, vive con su esposa y su pequeña hija de 7 años de edad, ellas dependen económicamente de él; don Oscar heredó de su padre el oficio de la carpintería, ya tiene su propia carpintería desde hace 4 años, trabaja junto a un hermano, su horario es de siete de la mañana  a cuatro de la tarde.
Con el crédito que está solicitando equipara mejor su negocio, comprara un motor para el torno, de esta manera agilizará su trabajo, dará mayor calidad en sus muebles y tendrá mejores ingresos, con los que respaldara el pago de la deuda.
Su aspiración es  tener un negocio con mejores ganancias y proveer de todo lo necesario a su familia.
texts.en:
Oscar lives with his wife and 7-year old daughter who depend on him financially. He learned carpentry from his father, and he and his brother have had their own carpentry workshop for four years. He works from 7 am to 4 pm.

With the loan money that he is seeking, Oscar plans to buy better tools for his business as well as a motor for his lathe. These purchases will speed up his work and improve the quality of the furniture he makes, leading to greater earnings with which to pay off his loan.

Oscar hopes to have an even better business in the future, and earn more money to pay for all his family's needs.

loans.use: Buy a motor for his lathe

loans.name: Philipina

texts.en:
Philipina is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives at her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Philipina dreams of establishing a wholesale business in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting of Kes 30,000, she wants to purchase stock of wheat flour, maize flour, rice, soaps and sugar for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of wheat flour, maize flour, rice, soaps and sugar for sale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase more accessories, makeup, and cosmetics for resale to the women in her area.

loans.name: Maxima

texts.en:
Maxima owns and operates a food stall. She has been successful in this business for years, and she repaid her previous loan used for the business. She also finds ways to improve her income through all her hard work.

In relation to this, she would like to take a new loan to increase her profits. She is requesting an amount of 15,000 PHP (Philippine Pesos) to buy products like meat, rice, vegetables, condiments, and seasonings in larger quantities.

Maxima hopes to expand her business and to also start up and have her own variety store. She wishes for her children to be always healthy and that their needs for each day will be sufficient. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT (Center for Community Transformation) community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for raw ingredients like rice, pork, chicken, and vegetables, and for products needed in her business.

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia owns and operates a variety store business to earn a living. She has been successful in this business for three years, and she repaid her previous loan used for the business. She also finds ways to improve her income by operating her 'taho' (a snack food made of fresh soft/silken tofu, arnibal, and sago pearl that similar to tapioca pearls) business.

Relative to this, she would like to take a new loan to increase her product inventory. She is requesting an amount of PHP 20,000 to buy more quantities and varieties of grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

In the future, Lilia wants to improve her business and dreams that her children will be able to complete their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Penila

texts.en:
Penila is 48 years old and a married mother of ten children, three of whom are in school. She has been farming vegetables for the past year in the Philippines.

Penila  is now requesting her second loan from NWTF for PHP 10000 to purchase additional vegetable seeds and fertilizers for her farm. In the future, she would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional vegetable seeds and fertilizers for her farm

loans.name: Maricar

texts.en:
Filah Marae is the only child in the family. Her mother Maricar, who is a member of NWTF, supports the family through her pig raising business in the Philippines.

Filah Marae is studying for a Bachelor of Science in Hotel and Restaurant Management, and is currently in the 2nd year of this 4-year course.

Maricar, Filah Marae's mother, is borrowing PHP 20,000 to pay for tuition fees of the 1st semester for school year 2014-2015. Filah Marae plans to graduate and be gainfully employed.

loans.use: to pay for tuition fees for her daughter.

loans.name: Jowenda

texts.en:
Jowenda is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business buying and selling bamboo weavings in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 14,000 PHP (Philippine Pesos) through NWTF (Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc.) to purchase materials like bamboo, etc. for her business making bamboo weavings.

Jowenda has been in this business for three years. She earns more income from a general store.

Jowenda has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase materials, like bamboo, etc.

loans.name: Almaton

texts.en:
Almaton is 33 years old and married with three children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc.

Almaton has borrowed and repaid 1 loan from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 1 year and also earns an income from fishing.

She aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Wedzine

texts.en:
Wedzine appreciates her previous loan that improved her living standards. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income.

She would like to apply for a loan to buy more stocks of wheat flour, maize flour, beans, rice, and sugar. She thanks Yehu Microfinance Trust for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of wheat flour, maize flour, beans, rice, and sugar.

loans.name: Kayango

texts.en:
Kayango has operated a milk selling business at the market for the past three years, selling to passersby and neighbours. She cites seasonality as her major business challenge.

Kayango has requested this loan to purchase gallons of milk for resale. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase gallons of milk for resale

loans.name: Sharon

texts.en:
Sharon, a 27-year-old married mother of two, works hard to provide for her family. For the past year she has run a general store in the Philippines, and also earns an income from selling vegetables.

Having borrowed and repaid a previous loan from NWTF, Sharon is requesting a new one for PHP 10000 to purchase more items to sell such as soap, shampoo, eggs, canned goods, chips, etc. She aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell such as soap, shampoo, eggs, canned goods, chips, etc

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is 62 years old and married with six children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines. She has been running the general store for five years and also earns an income from food vending.
 
Nancy has requested a 20,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, soap, chips, soft drinks, spices, and eggs. She has borrowed and paid 19 loans from NWTF before this loan. She aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, soap, chips, soft drinks, spices, and eggs

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace appreciates the support of the previous loans that helped her to buy furniture for her business. Here again, she comes to you requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to buy 20 chairs for her business needed because of the expansion.  She has attracted more customers out of her good services.

loans.use: to buy 20 chairs for her business.

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
Marissa is 30 years old and married with three children. She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Marissa has been raising pigs for four years and also earns additional income from food vending.

Marissa is borrowing 17,000 PHP through NWTF to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs. She is working tirelessly towards the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Nzara

texts.en: Nzara appreciates her previous loan that improved her living standards. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She would like to apply for a loan to buy more stock of household consumables, wheat flour, maize flour, rice and sugar. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy more stock of household consumables , wheat flour, maize flour, rice and sugar.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy agricultural supplies for her coffee plants.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to install cameras and a screen to control his Supermarket.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fruit and vegetables to supply her business.

loans.name: Tupendane C Group

texts.en:
Emanuel, who is in his mid-30s, is a married father of two young children. One of his kids is in school. He has been selling a variety of foods and drinks such as sodas, juice, water, chips, fried chicken, miskaki and eggs for ten years now. He has a second, similar shop run by an employee, although Emanuel still monitors and supervises the shop. He is working from 10:00 am till after midnight, and he is able to make a very good profit per month. 

This will be Emanuel's twelfth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used his previous loans, all since repaid, to purchase a motorcycle, a fridge and inventory for his food businesses. He used his profits to buy a radio, a sofa set, and a plot of land, and has built a small house at his village place. 

He will use this loan to buy Irish potatoes and drinks, including sodas for his new branch. 

Emanuel dreams of owning a wholesale shop and is so happy with the loans which have allowed him to improve his life. Emanuel will share this loan with his loan group, "Tupendane C" , which has two members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy Irish potatoes and drinks, including sodas for his new branch.

loans.name: Pricyl

texts.en:
Pricyl is 30 years old and married with four children.

Pricyl works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to buy more groceries to sell in her general store.

Pricyl has borrowed and paid three loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for two years, and also earns an income from raising pigs.

Pricyl aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell in her general store

loans.name: Mila

texts.en: Mila is 38 years old and married with five children. She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines. Mila is borrowing PHP 17,000 through NWTF to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies. She has been farming rice for 17 years and also earns additional income from raising pigs. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream, to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida is 58 years old and married with seven children.

She earns a living by pig fattening in the Philippines. Zenaida is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to purchase additional feeds and rice bran.

Zenaida has been pig fattening for ten years and also earns an additional income from fishing.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional feed and rice bran

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is 54 years old and married with three children. She works very hard to provide for them.
